Oral Answers to Questions

Page: 451

Update on National Research Foundation's Work

1 Dr Lim Wee Kiak asked the Prime Minister (a) whether the National Research Foundation has achieved its objectives; (b) what is the number of patents filed in Singapore annually for the past five years; and (c) what are the measures that will be implemented to increase Singapore's creativity and knowledge-based output.

The Deputy Prime Minister and Coordinating Minister for National Security and Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Teo Chee Hean) (for the Prime Minister) : Mr Speaker, Sir, the National Research Foundation (NRF) seeks to strengthen Singapore's R&D capabilities, encourage greater innovation and nurture the growth of technology-based enterprises in Singapore. This will help Singapore to remain competitive and create high value jobs and prosperity for Singaporeans in the future.

Over the last decade, we have invested heavily in research and development to grow knowledge-intensive industries and services for sustained economic growth. Singapore is moving steadily towards an innovation-driven knowledge-based economy.

Singapore has made a good start in establishing itself as an R&D hub. Supported by public investment in R&D, Singapore's universities have developed into internationally-competitive research-intensive universities to complement their strong education mission and enhance their impact on our economy and society. Through sustained and substantial R&D investments, NUS and NTU have built up five Research Centres of Excellence (RCEs), which perform cutting-edge research in fields such as Quantum Technologies and Earth Sciences.

Page: 452

Our local universities and research institutions have established collaborations with renowned research universities, and anchored world-class researchers and top faculty in Singapore. For example, the Campus for Research Excellence and Technological Enterprise (CREATE) houses interdisciplinary research centres from some of the world's best research universities, such as MIT, Berkeley, Peking university and ETH Zurich. NRF has also awarded 48 Fellowships to top young researchers from around the world to pursue groundbreaking research in Singapore.

Our universities and A*STAR have been critical in providing the R&D knowledge base to draw in investments from multinational companies. For example, in 2011, Infineon Technologies injected around S$88 million to expand its production capacity and research and development in Singapore, which included setting up the Semiconductor Supply Chain Science Centre to carry out collaborative research with the universities. Likewise, A*STAR has forged strategic public-private partnerships with key companies, bringing investments into Singapore and creating good, high-value jobs. Over the past one year, companies such as GE Global Research, Baidu, L'Oreal and Applied Materials have set up new R&D activities as well as collaborations with A*STAR research institutes in Singapore.

Dr Lim asked about the number of patents filed in Singapore annually. Every year, around 1,500 to 2,000 patents are filed worldwide as a result of R&D done in Singapore. However, this is only one measure of innovation. The best measure of success is when research outcomes are coupled with innovation to translate R&D output into solutions with economic and social impact. Singapore has benefited from strategic R&D investments in areas such as biomedical sciences, clean water and interactive & digital media. These have sharpened our competitive edge and generated new growth. Our biomedical sciences manufacturing output has more than tripled from $6.3 billion in 2000 to $23.3 billion in 2010, and created 14,000 jobs by end 2010. Investments in Clean Water technologies have helped develop Singapore into a Global Hydro-hub; in the water sector value-add expanded by $590 million and 2,300 jobs were created over the period 2006 to 2010. R&D has also supported a growing interactive & digital media sector, where value-add expanded by 26% from 2007 to 2010.

The Government is investing $16.1 billion over a five-year period from 2011 to 2015 as part of the RIE2015 plan to boost research, innovation and enterprise. This is a 20% increase over the previous five years. Key thrusts under RIE2015 include allocating a greater proportion of R&D to focus on economic outcomes, providing more support for commercialisation of R&D into products and services, and fostering R&D collaborations across disciplines and between the public and private sectors.

By steadily building up our scientific and technological capabilities, we can grow Singapore to be among the most research-intensive, innovative and entrepreneurial economies in the world. This will form the foundation for our future competitiveness and economy, creating good jobs and improving the lives of Singaporeans.

Dr Lim Wee Kiak (Nee Soon) : Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to thank the Deputy Prime Minister for the very comprehensive answer. Sir, I have a few supplementary questions. First, in a letter to the Forum Page dated 24 July 2012, entitled "Innovations: individuals must be properly rewarded and recognised", the writer claimed that there is a blanket rule that companies or employers own all new ideas created by employees. Is that true? If that is true, it may stifle creativity. I would like to ask the Deputy Prime Minister what is the reward to the individual inventors under our existing laws. Will the Government introduce legislation similar to the Employees' Patent Act in some of the states in the US that protects employees against a perceived disparity in bargaining power with respect to patent rights agreements between employees and employers, where the inventor will also have the right to continue research or development of the product or knowledge that he invented?

Page: 453

Mr Teo Chee Hean : Sir, that is a very specific question and I would not get into it because it involves intellectual property agreements between individuals and companies or research labs which they work for, and from which they draw resources and perhaps other supporting staff and activity, and perhaps even foundational research, precursor research which goes into the particular innovation or patent which the person or individual has rights to. I think I would not want to go into specifics on this one, but this is an active area of study in Singapore the whole area of intellectual property rights, patent rights and so on and we do have to find the correct balance between individuals and the institutions which they work for.

Mr Zaqy Mohamad (Chua Chu Kang) : Sir, I thank the Deputy Prime Minister for his answer. I have just one clarification. How does NRF exactly measure its success in helping companies or researchers in commercialising the R&D or IP? I noticed that the Deputy Prime Minister gave some figures. Are those based on revenue returns or on return on investments based on what NRF puts in? I also have other side questions. Does NRF have KPIs for local companies it reaches out to, and how many local companies are involved with the NRF today?

Mr Teo Chee Hean : NRF does have KPIs for the investment funds that we put into the various research institutions, and so does A*STAR. I do not have the precise number of local companies which we are working with. We do work with a range of companies, A*STAR particularly. Because A*STAR does research in areas which are much closer to the immediately exploitable economic areas. For example, in water technologies, there will be very, very close interactions with many companies, both local and foreign. Certainly, for the biomedical sciences, that is so. But there is also much more foundational and fundamental research which is carried out to build the knowledge base upon which applied research is done, and on which the specific innovations can then draw on in order to create new industries and new products. So, I do not have the number of precisely how many individual Singapore companies are being impacted by each of these projects.

Page: 453

Effectiveness of Efforts to Integrate New Immigrants

2 Ms Tan Su Shan asked the Prime Minister whether recent efforts to integrate new immigrants have been effective and what the specific goals to be achieved from these integration efforts are.

The Minister, Prime Minister's Office (Ms Grace Fu Hai Yien) (for the Prime Minister) : Mr Speaker, our goals are to encourage our new immigrants to integrate into society by embracing our Singaporean values and norms and contributing to their new homeland, and to strengthen the bonds between new immigrants and local-born Singaporeans. Integration needs to occur at all levels of society and involve as many locals and new immigrants as possible, in order to be effective and sustainable.

Page: 454

The National Integration Council (NIC) was therefore established in 2009 to encourage ground-up initiatives to integrate people, and also to involve the people, private and public sectors. The NIC has made inroads into the key spheres of interaction between new immigrants and locals, namely, our schools, the workplace and the community. For example, the People's Association Integration Council was formed in July 2012 to support the network of 87 Integration and Naturalisation Committees, one in each constituency. More than 1,200 Integration and Naturalisation Champions from these Committees help newcomers settle down in the community and establish social networks with Singaporeans. Through the Community Integration Fund, the NIC has provided grants to support some 200 integration initiatives organised by students, companies and community and cultural groups.

We monitor the effectiveness of such initiatives through indicators such as participation levels and feedback, while recognising that such measurements are at best proxy indicators. For example, feedback collated from new citizens who have participated in the Singapore Citizenship Journey indicated that the programme had enriched their knowledge of our country's key institutions and values. Many also felt encouraged to take part in community activities after attending the programme.

We also take reference from independent research conducted by think tanks and academic institutions. One such study by the Institute of Policy Studies showed that 85% of new immigrants attested to friendships with local born Singaporeans in the heartlands. As integration is a long-term process, it is still too early to conclude on the effectiveness of the initiatives and programmes. Nonetheless, more must be done. Student leaders and educators, employers and unions, grassroots and community leaders as well as new immigrants must join us in this important task of strengthening our social cohesion.

I encourage our new immigrants to also actively seek out opportunities to contribute to our community. This is a good way to expand their social network, gain first-hand experience of our norms and culture, and settle down in their new home more quickly. We seek Singaporeans' understanding and patience as we work towards the common goal of strengthening our social harmony.

Ms Tan Su Shan (Nominated Member) : Sir, I thank the Minister for her reply. My supplementary question arises from having read with great interest the latest release from the Prime Minister's Office on "Our Population, Our Future". It does appear that our numbers for new immigrants and PRs peaked in 2008 at 100,000 granted, to recent numbers in 2011 of around 42,000 granted. So, my question here is: is this quantum the target that we are aiming towards? Are we still aiming towards sharp declines in this quantum, or is it the quality of these new immigrants and PRs that we grant what we are looking at?

Ms Grace Fu Hai Yien : Mr Speaker, with your indulgence, I would like to invite the Member to file a separate Parliamentary Question (PQ) because I believe that this clarification is very different from what the original PQ was meant for.

Page: 455

Mr Speaker : Yes, please.

Mr Zaqy Mohamad : I would like to thank the Minister for her comprehensive reply. I agree in fact that the approach must be sustainable and impactful. Sir, I would like to ask the Ministry if the ground-up approach is too narrow and too reliant on grassroots and voluntary organisations. Also, while the funding set aside, for example funding of $10 million to PA, is impactful, would the Government consider a more comprehensive integration programme undertaken by Government agencies that engage new citizens before they are approved for citizenship, or subject to approval to ensure the programme is well covered, and all new citizens can integrate effectively, regardless of background, including the high-income groups that are often difficult to reach by grassroots organisations?

Apart from new citizens, would the Government also consider an assimilation programme to address the one million plus foreign manpower here? Many of them are also residing among us in the HDB heartlands. Would such a programme not lead to better understanding of our social norms, race and cultures as well?

Ms Grace Fu Hai Yien : Sir, I thank the Member for the clarification, which gives me the opportunity to explain what the Council has been doing. In fact, when we talk about community effort, it is a very broad definition. We are involving employers from the day, as he has mentioned, new workers come in, and how do we inculcate into them the daily lives of Singaporeans, and how do we educate them on what is the acceptable social norm. So, that is happening at the Work Pass application process. All foreign workers, when they come to Singapore, will have to go through a public education process. It is really targeted at workers and it is done on a very broad base. I would say that all foreign workers, when they come to Singapore, would receive some education. At the same time, MOM and its team will actually go down to the foreign workers' dormitories to spread the public message about how do they keep the amenity intact and not disturb the neighbourhood. So, this is something that is on-going.

We classify our work into three levels: first, what we call a functional integration; in their daily lives, what is the expected norm, try to tone down after a certain hour. It is very basic and very essential for people just to understand the expectation of Singaporeans, and the basic living in the midst of Singaporeans.

The second level is really socialisation: how do we help newcomers, whether it is workers or immigrants, to establish social network, and that is done at various levels. It is not just at the community level. It is also at the schools at the Primary, Secondary and even tertiary levels. We would like to have the schools involved and MOE is represented in the Integration Council. So, again, it is very broad based, very extensive engagement at the school levels.

Third is really what we call "building a mutual trust". It is a deeper level of understanding and emotional attachment to their new country and their new place of residence, and that is really something where we need community help to come in, both in the PA setting as well as in various other settings. For example, some VWOs have come forward and introduced programmes for new citizens to join them. And that is really a very effective way of building attachment for new citizens with the local community. It is not something that the Government could do single-handedly. We involve all stakeholders in this employers, schools, VWOs, people sector to help us in this process of establishing a stronger social bonding with the new immigrants.

Page: 456

Review of Government Procurement Processes

3 Mr Zaqy Mohamad asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance (a) whether the Government's procurement processes need a further review following its recent review in which it is found that the processes are adequate; (b) whether the Ministry will consider making GeBIZ more accessible and transparent to the public so that interested vendors are always alerted to relevant opportunities and to avoid opportunities falling only to sole bidders; and (c) whether there are systems in place to alert relevant authorities on potential lapses in procurement procedures such as single-bid tenders or tenders that allow responses within a short time span.

4 Mr Png Eng Huat asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance in each of the years from 2010 to date (a) how many tenders in GeBIZ attracted only one bidder; (b) how many of such tenders were awarded subsequently; (c) what is the average tender period in days for these awarded tenders; and (d) what is the total value of these awarded tenders reported.

5 Mr Baey Yam Keng asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance what is the rationale behind the discrepancy in the Government's treatment of tenders where the Government may award a contract to a sole tenderer, but requires a second tender exercise when there is only one bidder for the rental of market stalls.

The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance (Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam) : Mr Speaker, may I have your permission to take Question Nos 3, 4 and 5 together?

Mr Speaker : Yes, please.

Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam : Thank you. I thank Members for their questions on Government procurement practices. Members would have received the latest audit findings from the Auditor-General, several of which had to do with procurement lapses. We take these findings very seriously, and are addressing them systematically in Government so as to reduce the chances of recurrence.

Let me first put matters in perspective. Our system of public sector procurement is on the whole in good working order. The system is based on the principles of open and fair competition for public tenders, getting value for money, and an unequivocal stance against corruption or any other abuse of the trust placed in public officers.

Our procurement rules are sound, and we continue to review and improve on them. The rules are in line with standards in most other reputable jurisdictions. They put in place checks and balances without adding unnecessary layers of bureaucracy. The majority of public sector officers abide by the rules and live up to the conduct we expect of them as stewards of public funds. But in a system with 80,000 procurements each year, we will have lapses even as we strive to avoid them. We therefore place great importance on independent audits of public sector procurement, keeping open all channels for possible irregularities to be reported, and taking robust enforcement action when any wrong-doing is established.

It is therefore a whole system not just the rules governing procurement, but honest officers who implement the rules, diligent supervisors, and regular audits. When questions are raised, we investigate promptly. Officials who are negligent are subject to disciplinary proceedings. Where corruption or fraud is suspected, an officer faces the full measure of the law. Everyone knows that, and it deters wrong-doing.

Page: 457

The Government also acknowledges problems openly, even if it brings embarrassment to any of our agencies. It is how our system must continue to operate, so that its integrity is never in doubt. This is also why Singapore is widely recognised internationally as having a clean system of government that works.

Let me now go on to the rules. MOF regularly reviews the procurement rules. For example, in 2010, we took several important measures to reduce the risks of opportunities for procurement fraud. Our aim is to preserve fair competition and to reduce the risk of wrong-doings, but not to pile on rules that will hinder the vast majority of legitimate procurements and reduce public sector efficiency. Let me share how we intend to make further improvements, in the spirit of this approach.

Our procurement rules are calibrated to the value and risk of the purchase. The approval process is highly centralised for high-value projects. Projects above $80 million must be approved by the Development Planning Committee comprising three Cabinet Ministers, after rigorous scrutiny by the senior officials in the Ministry of Finance and the Ministry concerned, before tenders can be called. Roughly half of the total value of public sector procurements each year goes through this Development Planning Committee process. Further, for all procurements above $70,000, the award of the tender must be approved by a committee comprising at least three senior officers. These tenders with more stringent processes account for the bulk of the value about 96% of the total value of Government procurements each year.

Approval of lower value procurements is typically decentralised for greater efficiency and responsiveness. Even so, the process is governed by a clear set of rules. Singapore is not unique in this. Decentralised procurement is practised in most advanced countries with efficient procurement systems, such as Australia and the United Kingdom.

For common goods and services, some forms of centralised purchasing are, in fact, being practised today. We have over 50 bulk contracts which all Government agencies can tap on, covering items such as office equipment and professional services. In total, they amount to more than $4 billion in value, which is quite a substantial sum.

Where there are advantages in doing so, our Government agencies are taking steps to centralise procurement and pool the procurement expertise. For example, the Ministry of Home Affairs and the Singapore Sports Council have recently embarked on efforts to do so, bringing together procurement that is currently carried out by different departments within their respective agencies. Smaller Ministries and agencies are also coming together to share procurement expertise and explore pooling within clusters of similar agencies or agencies with similar needs.

However, we must strike a judicious balance. As the needs of public sector agencies have grown more complex and varied over time, it will be a bad idea to centralise all procurement. We must allow our agencies to retain sufficient flexibility and autonomy to perform their roles effectively, but ensure that regular audits are undertaken to preserve the integrity of the system.

Page: 458

MOF will enhance the rules on the handling of single bids. Over the past three years, procurements that attracted single bidders accounted for about 2% of the total value of contracts awarded each year. Most of these procurements were quotations of below $70,000 in value each. A number of tenders above $70,000 in value also attracted single bids despite an average tender opening period of 20 days.

There are practical reasons why we should not prevent contracts from being awarded in such cases. But we will tighten approval procedures and ensure that quotations are kept open long enough to encourage potential suppliers to take part.

For procurements where only a single bid is received, MOF will require the officers responsible to provide additional justifications to the Approving Authority within each agency, setting out why they consider the single bid competitive or reflective of market prices, before a decision is made to award such a contract. Depending on the size of their procurements and the risks involved, individual agencies may decide on other enhancements to the approval process where there is a single bid.

We will also extend the minimum opening period for suppliers to submit bids for quotations quotations are those contracts of between $3,000 and $70,000 in value; above $70,000, you would have to call a tender from the current requirement of four working days to seven working days. This again is a matter of balance. We want to give suppliers a full chance to participate, but not extend the opening period for these lower value contracts to a point where it slows down the routine functioning of Government. Where there are exigencies which require a shorter opening period, the approval of a Director or equivalent officer may be sought.

For larger procurements, which are handled by tenders, the minimum opening period is already set at 14 calendar days, or 25 calendar days if the tender is covered under Singapore's international trade agreements. In practice, many tenders are open for longer than the minimum period. In fact, the average is at least a week longer than the minimum period.

Another area which we are reviewing concerns term contracts. These are contracts which run for a specified period of time. The Auditor-General has observed that some Government agencies have been overcharged by vendors for work items that have not been priced upfront in term contracts. MOF will be tightening the rules to require that agencies assure themselves that they are charged at fair market prices for items that are not priced in the term contracts.

Let me now turn to GeBIZ. All Government agencies are required to post their invitations to tender or quote on the Government Electronic Business portal, or GeBIZ. It is an accessible platform, and levels the playing field especially for smaller suppliers. To ensure transparency, Government agencies are also required to publish on GeBIZ the schedule of bids and notices of award after the tender or quotation has closed.

Anyone can search for business opportunities easily on GeBIZ. They do not need to register. It is an improvement from the past where suppliers had to search the newspapers sometimes newspapers in different languages to spot relevant opportunities. It is also easy for suppliers to register as GeBIZ Trading Partners. They get a free user account, which enables them to download quotation and tender documents, and submit their bids electronically.

Page: 459

The GeBIZ system is not passive. GeBIZ Trading Partners can sign up to receive alerts on relevant business opportunities. Government agencies may also alert suppliers to opportunities posted openly on GeBIZ through the GeBIZ alert system, or through phone calls or by publicity on their own websites. This is to ensure that the contract receives sufficient attention from potential bidders, without compromising fairness and transparency.

MOF will encourage agencies to proactively alert potential suppliers when procuring unusual or atypical products or services, in case these suppliers are not registered with GeBIZ or are not already receiving alerts. This is a good practice that we will encourage agencies to adopt.

The majority of the procurement-related lapses that have been pointed out by the Auditor-General were not due to a lack of rules. They were caused by public officers failing to follow existing procurement rules and principles. MOF has sent a strong message to all Permanent Secretaries and heads of Government agencies emphasising public officers' accountability for the use of public funds. The core of a clean and functioning procurement system lies in active oversight and supervision within each Ministry and agency. Supervisors and Approving Authorities must be conscientious in asking questions.

MOF has developed checklists to guide officers on what to look out for when giving approvals at various stages of the procurement process. Officers who do a good job in safeguarding the integrity of procurements should also be recognised for their contributions to this important function.

However, there will still be no substitute for robust audit and enforcement. The Auditor-General's Office, which is an independent body under the Constitution, as well as auditors within our agencies, provides critical checks in our system. Government agencies must follow up with independent and thorough investigations into all suspected irregularities arising from these audits. They should also act on any credible information received from the public, or from public officers themselves.

Where officers have been lax in implementing procurement rules, we will take disciplinary actions. In fact, for each of the cases raised by the Auditor-General in his latest Report, further investigations have been conducted or are being conducted by our agencies, and officers who have been found negligent have been reprimanded or warned.

As I emphasised earlier, we have also consistently sought to enforce the law through the Courts when officers are suspected of legal offences, such as fraud. Their position or rank does not matter. We will continue to enforce both our rules and the laws vigorously, so as to uphold public confidence in the integrity of the Government procurement system, and trust in the Public Service as an institution.

Mr Cedric Foo Chee Keng (Pioneer) : Sir, I serve on the Public Accounts Committee and I am very heartened to hear the Deputy Prime Minister setting the tone from the top: that he and his Government intend to keep Singapore corruption-free this is something which separates us from many parts of the world.

Page: 460

However, I would like to ask the Deputy Prime Minister whether or not he thinks that competency in procurement procedures is lacking in the Civil Service and, if so, does it make sense to create a career track primarily for procurement officers who can be posted to various Ministries, by having a definitive track to develop and to institutionalise procurement expertise within the Civil Service.

Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam : I thank Mr Cedric Foo for his question and suggestion. Firstly, yes, competency has been a problem. Part of the problem has been a tendency sometimes to delegate procurement to a very junior level, which should not be the case, and not to adequately supervise the process from start to end. And we are correcting that. By and large, the system is functioning well. The majority of officers and their supervisors are doing a good job, but there are more lapses than we think acceptable. We face rotation of procurement officers and natural attrition as well, and we are going to improve the system. Firstly, by having more training, better checklists for every officer to follow. Secondly, we are looking into the suggestion which Mr Cedric Foo has mentioned, which is a career track for procurement officers. This is an important function in Government, critical to confidence in the system as a whole, and it deserves some specialisation.

Mr Zaqy Mohamad : I thank the Deputy Prime Minister for the comprehensive reply to my parliamentary question (PQ) and for assuring the public that we are constantly reviewing the procurement policies in order to retain public trust. I have two supplementary questions.

Firstly, how do we ensure that there is a fine line between the tightening of our procurement policies as well as going after officers with regard to not making it too difficult for businesses to continue to provide services to the Government?

Secondly, the concern is whether this could lead to more bureaucracy that would impede the productivity of our officers. Also, in relation to these policy improvements, would the Ministry involve consultation with the business community to allay some of these concerns, whether it is cosy relationship with incumbents, or closed tenders and so forth.

With regard to procurement, in the past, I was told that they used to have a test on the Instruction Manuals (IM) for Civil Service officers. This is a common practice in the private sector, with compliance tests being done among officers in the private sector. I am wondering whether the Ministry would consider doing that in the Civil Service. So, a compliance test for the IM or procurement policies.

Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam : Firstly, I agree fully with Mr Zaqy Mohamad. As I emphasised in my earlier reply, we have to find the right balance. We cannot pile on rules and think that by piling rules we can prevent fraud. People will get around rules if they want to. We need a strong audit function, and we need to show through our actions that we take every irregularity seriously, and disciplinary or legal proceedings are initiated in every case of irregularity.

We do have to shift the balance in certain categories of bids, and especially, as I mentioned, for smaller value quotations. We do think that a longer opening period will encourage fair competition and it will encourage agencies and their officers to plan better in advance for needs do not issue a procurement at the last minute and limit the opening period. So it requires a little more planning in advance, rather than more layers of bureaucracy. We do require that when you have consultation with potential suppliers the rules already require that these be open and transparent. Agencies should not have consultations with a few selected bidders who may then get unintended advantage. This is an extremely important principle. There will be a need for what we call "Request for Information". Often, the agency or the officers are not sufficiently familiar with the technicalities of the product or service, and it is extremely useful to get information from potential suppliers. But that should be an open process, open to anyone to attend. So it is an example of how we are trying to find a balance, maintain open and fair competition, checks and balances in the system, but avoid adding on more layers of bureaucracy that can slow things down, particularly for small value transactions which are quite important to the regular functioning of Government.

Page: 461

As far as how we compare with the private sector, we did a thorough review of this a year and a half ago, after the SLA case. We found that, actually, the public sector procurement practices and procedures were certainly no inferior, and are, in fact, in general, more stringent than what the private sector practises. They also easily pass muster as far as international comparison is concerned.

Mr Baey Yam Keng (Tampines) : Sir, while it is not Government procurement per se, I would like the Deputy Prime Minister's response to my parliamentary question (PQ) about the second tender exercise where there was only one bidder for rental of market stalls whether that is a standard practice that is applied across the board for all other rental, leasing or purchase opportunities offered by the Government.

Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam : Let me explain the case which Mr Baey Yam Keng has raised. This concerns market stalls which, under previous rules in fact, for a long period of time, you could not award what we call a revenue procurement where you are not actually selling a service by the Government but you are awarding the right to operate. You cannot give an award if a reserve rent was not met by the bidder. That was a long-standing practice.

Sometime early this year, in March, NEA changed the rules because it was trying to maximise utilisation of rentals of market stalls and it wanted to allow for bids that reflected fair market value, even if they were below our reserve rent. What they did was to allow for any number of bids to come in, but where it was a single bid, they required a second tender to establish fair market value. And that process has been quite useful, because we found often that in the second tender, the prices varied quite a bit, compared to the first tender. So, it is not a requirement that there be more than one bid. In fact, very often, in the second tender, you still get only one bid. But it is a check on the system because we had done away with the reserve rent. The principles are basically the same. Whether it is a procurement tender or revenue tender, agencies can award contracts to single bids if they are satisfied that it is at fair market value.

Mr Gerald Giam Yean Song (Non-Constituency Member) : Mr Speaker, I am glad the Government is committed to keeping open the channels for irregularities to be reported. My question is: are all officers aware of these channels, and how can they be assured of protection from victimisation as whistleblowers?

Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam : We have made clear these channels in the public service. An officer can report to the Permanent Secretary, the Head of the Civil Service, and can make a report to the Public Service Commission, which is an independent body under the Constitution. All effort will be taken to protect the identity of the person to the extent that is feasible and permissible under the law. So, we are quite serious about this. And we do get feedback from public officers. Quite apart from the public at large, we do get feedback from public officers that is very useful and is taken very seriously.

Impact of Livestock Export Rule Changes on the Annual Observance of Korban in Singapore

6 Assoc Prof Fatimah Lateef asked the Minister for Information, Communications and the Arts and Minister-in-charge of Muslim Affairs with the new regulatory framework by the Australian authorities on the export of livestock, what plans are in place for the yearly korban held in Singapore and how is MUIS adapting to these changes.

The Minister for Information, Communications and the Arts and Minister-in-charge of Muslim Affairs (Assoc Prof Dr Yaacob Ibrahim) : Sir, on 1 March 2012, the Australian government introduced a new regulatory framework known as the Exporter Supply Chain Assurance System, to ensure that Australian livestock exported to different countries are treated in accordance to stipulated animal welfare standards.

With this change, Australian exporters seeking a permit to export livestock to Singapore must comply with stringent requirements, including how the animals are transported and handled. This will come into effect on 1 September this year.

Singapore currently imports livestock from Australia once a year for our Muslims to perform the sacrifice ritual better known as korban. The new Australian regulations mean that all mosques intending to offer korban in October this year must meet the standards. Prior audits must be carried out by an independent and internationally accredited auditor to certify that standards are complied with before the mosques are allowed to offer korban with Australian livestock.

Sir, to help our mosques meet Australia's new requirements, the Islamic Religious Council of Singapore (MUIS) has worked with the Agri-Food & Veterinary Authority of Singapore (AVA) to improve our existing systems and processes for korban. This includes developing standard operational procedures for all mosques, training of all personnel involved in korban operations and ensuring that all mosques offering korban services have the necessary space and facilities to meet the stringent requirements. In addition, MUIS has arranged for audits to be carried out at 16 selected mosques to ensure the revised korban systems and procedures meet Australia's new requirements.

The Australian exporter and the auditors are finalising the report for submission to the Australian authorities in order to obtain the approval to export to Singapore. I wish to assure the Member that MUIS is committed to helping our mosques meet the stringent requirements under the new Australian regulatory framework, so as to minimise disruptions to the annual korban rites. However, despite the best efforts of all parties involved, there is a possibility that not all mosques will be able to perform the korban this year. If this happens, it will have an impact on the supply and prices of korban livestock, as well as the number of participating mosques. The community must be ready for this probable outcome. MUIS, Sir, will continue to do its best to minimise disruptions to the annual korban rites. It will keep the Muslim community updated on the progress and status.

Page: 463

Assoc Prof Fatimah Lateef (Marine Parade) : Sir, I thank the Minister for the response. Can I find out, on average, how many of the mosques will pass the audit that is being carried out currently? There is a growing concern among the Muslim community about how far this can proceed as in previous years. Are we looking at alternative sources of livestock, besides Australia, and, if so, which are the other countries that we are looking at? Also, how are we engaging the stakeholders, including the mosques, as well as some of the Muslim organisations that are used to doing this, because there is a growing concern and feedback from the ground and there is some level of confusion involved?

Assoc Prof Dr Yaacob Ibrahim : Sir, we have been engaging the key stakeholders, in this case, the mosques, and, in fact, there are also some organisations that have been doing so every year and we have been engaging them also. In fact, through releases to the media, we have informed the public of the process which is ongoing at this stage. So far, we have audited 16 mosques, and the audited results have been passed on to the Australian exporter for them to pass on to the Australian authorities. We hope that they will do so as soon as possible so that the authorities can give us the clearance for the 16 mosques. We are hoping to clear 35 mosques this year. The numbers will depend largely on how the Australian authorities will view the 16 mosques which have already been audited.

Speed wise, we hope that the Australian exporter can do it as quickly as possible. We are basically in touch with him on a daily basis to ensure that whatever documents that he needs will be supplied immediately. In fact, we have given all the necessary documents, including all the test results for him to forward on to the Australian authorities.

In terms of alternative sources, whatever sources that we are exploring, they would still have to meet the standard imposed by AVA. At this point in time, most of the countries around the region are importing from Australia. And therefore any plan to explore alternative sources for this year will be a bit tight for us. Certainly, going forward, we will consider all other options. Even New Zealand, for example, is an alternative source but at the same time, New Zealand also has the same stringent requirements for us to meet.

Finally, Sir, it is coming very, very close to korban because korban will be in October. We hope to be able to alert the community on a continuous basis where they may have to explore other options, including overseas korban, which already is in practice in Singapore for many, many years, to prepare for ourselves for some outcomes which we may not desire but we will try our best to avoid as far as possible.

Mr Zaqy Mohamad : Sir, I have two supplementary questions. Firstly, after speaking to many residents, many are concerned that the new regulations being put in over the last years, including this one, have led to the increasing costs of korban. In addition to Member Assoc Prof Fatimah Lateef's question earlier on alternative sources: would MUIS consider tiering? In the past, we used to send the supply by ship. Today we do it by airfreight, in order to ensure that there are different tiers and different options for citizens. The second question is in regards to the regulation by the Australian government in order to have korban done by specialised personnel. The sentiment in the community is not too favourable for this one because many had the practice of having to perform the rites themselves. Could the Minister comment if it is really necessary to abide by this regulation?

Page: 464

Assoc Prof Dr Yaacob Ibrahim : Sir, unfortunately, the answer is "yes" because that is a very strict requirement by the Australian authorities for us to ensure that whoever will be doing the slaughtering either have the necessary experience or qualification. In fact, through the audits of the 16 mosques, we are able to gather all the possible slaughterers for this year's korban to undergo training and audit at the same time. We understand the sentiments on the ground but unfortunately we need to import livestock from Australia. So, because of the requirement, we have to conform because if we do not, then we probably will not get anything from Australia altogether.

On the Member's first question, he may recall that for a couple of years, we had been bringing livestock by sea freight, but if he recall, there was one particular year where we were stuck because of some uncertainties in the weather and the animals came late. So given that uncertainty, MUIS decided to change from sea freight to airfreight. The cost borne by residents was not that great. ASEAN's Failure to Issue a Joint Communique at Recent Ministerial Meeting

(Impact on relations within ASEAN and between ASEAN and China, and on ASEAN Community 2015 goal)

7 Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs given ASEAN's unprecedented failure at its recent Ministerial Meeting to issue a joint communique, what are the implications of the deep divisions within ASEAN on strategic issues in the region and how it will affect ASEAN's ability to (i) deal with the emerging big power rivalry in the region; (ii) maintain ASEAN centrality; and (iii) fulfil its own goals to achieve an ASEAN Community in 2015.

8 Mr Alex Yam asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs with regard to the non-issuance of a joint communique during the recent ASEAN Ministerial Meeting, what is its impact on (i) Singapore; and (ii) the creation of an ASEAN community by 2015.

9 Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs if he will provide an update on the progress of negotiations between ASEAN and China for a code of conduct governing state behaviour in the South China Sea.

10 Mr Yee Jenn Jong asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs whether the failure by ASEAN to issue a joint statement over how to deal with claims on disputed territories in the South China Sea has affected working relationships within ASEAN and between ASEAN and China.

The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr K Shanmugam) : Mr Speaker, Sir, as the four questions are related, I will take the next four questions together.

Page: 465

Mr Speaker : Yes, please.

Mr K Shanmugam : Sir, to begin, I would like to restate Singapore's position on the South China Sea disputes. We are not a claimant state and we have always maintained that by their very nature, the specific territorial disputes in the South China Sea can only be settled by the parties directly concerned. However, that does not mean that Singapore has no interests in these disputes. Singapore's interests in the disputes, and the South China Sea (SCS), including on the question of freedom of navigation, have been stated clearly on several occasions and I do not propose to repeat them here.

It is useful to revisit the roots of ASEAN and how it is important to Singapore, as this will allow us to see the present developments in context. Many in this House know that Singapore was one of the founding members of ASEAN when it was established in 1967, along with Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines and Thailand. Our governments forged a common cause to maintain order in our region amidst the Cold War. Order was the essential precondition for development and prosperity for our peoples. We agreed to build a region united by a desire for stability and autonomy, promoting regional cooperation rather than competition, to fend off the alternative of a splintered Southeast Asia which would have become an arena for Cold War protagonists and their proxies.

Forty-five years on, this imperative still holds true. Building a strong, cohesive and autonomous ASEAN remains a key goal of our foreign policy. ASEAN helps its members manage the inherent complexities of the region as well as the evolving geopolitical order in the Asia-Pacific. Only a united ASEAN can credibly play a central role in engaging major powers towards the common goal of promoting regional peace, stability and prosperity. This strategic underpinning of ASEAN was given fresh impetus with the signing of our Charter in Singapore on 20 November 2007, which ushered ASEAN into a new phase of rules-based and principled regional norms. We agreed to build an ASEAN Community with a capital "C" in 2015. We recognised that an ASEAN Community is critical for maintaining ASEAN's competitiveness in the region and globally.

It was thus regrettable that no Joint Communique was issued at the 45th ASEAN Ministerial Meeting (AMM) in Phnom Penh in July 2012. I say this because the lack of a Joint Communique reflects disunity within ASEAN. ASEAN unity and centrality are key to the vision of the ASEAN Community. An ASEAN that is not united and cannot agree on a Joint Communique will have difficulties in playing a central role in the region. If we cannot address major issues affecting or happening in our region, ASEAN centrality will be seen as a slogan without a substance. Our ability to shape regional developments will diminish.

The reason why there was no Joint Communique was that there was no consensus on how to reflect recent developments in South China Sea in the Communique. We worked hard to find a compromise. But a compromise could not be reached because of the distance between positions taken by ASEAN members. While several draft formulations were put forward in an effort to bridge the gap, they were unfortunately rejected by one side or the other and the ASEAN Ministerial Meeting ended without a Joint Communique. All of us were heartened and appreciative that Indonesia managed to broker a common ASEAN position a week after the meetings ended. The ASEAN statement on "Six-Point Principles on the South China Sea" released on 20 July 2012 has gone some way to repair the damage to ASEAN's credibility, but more work needs to be done.

Page: 466

Some Members have asked about the impact of this incident on ASEAN's community building efforts. While the Phnom Penh meetings were a setback, I do not think that this in itself will divert us from our goals. We must press on with this important task despite the setback. As between ASEAN members, there is much that needs to be done and should be done to achieve the goal of an ASEAN Community. We must work on that within ASEAN. The setback in Phnom Penh will, of course, have some impact on ASEAN's relationships with external partners, in our push for ASEAN Community. The state of the global economy will also have an impact.

I said earlier that the failure to issue a Communique was linked to recent developments in the South China Sea. As the House knows, territorial claims in the South China Sea involve four ASEAN states and China. However, the claims are not the totality of ASEAN-China interactions, simply one part of many. All ASEAN members regard China as an important and valued partner. The strength of relations is demonstrated by our bilateral trade, which has grown from less than US$10 billion in 1991 to more than US$230 billion in 2010, making China ASEAN's largest trading partner and ASEAN China's third largest trading partner. The ASEAN-China Free Trade Agreement also entered into force on 1 January 2010. Beyond economics, ASEAN-China cooperation spans across 11 sectors, including environment, culture, and health. China has consistently been one of the strongest supporters of ASEAN's Community Building efforts, and has devoted effort and resources to help the region. It is clearly in ASEAN's and China's interests to maintain and strengthen cooperation for mutual benefit.

I have set out these areas of cooperation to provide some context to the heated debate on the outcome of the 45th AMM, the role that China may or may not have played and the impact on ASEAN-China relations. I think it is simplistic to try and identify any one actor or cause for what happened in Phnom Penh. There were many actors and many causes for the way the events unfolded.

ASEAN and all major powers share a common interest in maintaining peace and stability in the South China Sea. ASEAN needs to work closely with China, a claimant state, to promote cooperation and manage tensions in the area. A good start is the full implementation of the Declaration on the Conduct of Parties in the South China Sea (DOC) that both sides signed in 2002 to build confidence and trust amongst the participants. In the same way, ASEAN and China should start talks on a Code of Conduct in the South China Sea (COC) soon. Recent tensions in the South China Sea underscore the need for the COC discussions to take place sooner rather than later. That would be in everyone's interest.

I wish to underscore that ASEAN as a grouping cannot and does not take sides on the merits of a particular claim or claims. Nor do we attempt to resolve the disputes. That is a matter for the parties directly concerned. ASEAN's consistent collective position on the issue is that all parties should refrain from the use of force and work together to resolve disputes in accordance with international law, in particular the 1982 United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea.

Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong (Tampines) : I thank the Minister for a very comprehensive reply. It seems to many that Cambodia's action as Chair to block mention of the South China Sea disputes was to pander to China, which prefers to deal with the disputes bilaterally with each claimant state, rather than multilaterally. But the Cambodian Ambassador recently gave a different interpretation in his letter published in The Straits Times on 9 August 2012. He said that Cambodia was only acting from the position of principal as ASEAN Chair as it did not want to see ASEAN taking sides in the bilateral dispute which he said would jeopardise ASEAN.

Mr K Shanmugam : Can I clarify the Member's first question? Was it that the ASEAN Chair should play a major role in

Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong : My first question is, what is Singapore's position on whether ASEAN should have united stand on the South China Sea issue, and also on ASEAN playing an effective role?

Mr K Shanmugam : Sir, on the first question, the position is obviously yes. Most of my answer was directed at the importance of ASEAN taking a united stand, and that is necessary for ASEAN to play a central role. And in turn, ASEAN needs to play a central role if this region is to be peaceful and for us to achieve the vision of ASEAN 2015. As regards the second point, on whether Singapore as one of the founder members will seek to advise Cambodia, I think it is incumbent on all of us to help achieve consensus within ASEAN.

For example, after the 45th AMM which ended without a joint communique, Indonesia took it upon itself to try and come out with the Six-Point Principles, which everyone agreed to. So, I think it is incumbent on everyone to help the Chair, as well as try and bridge whatever gaps there may be to try and get consensus.

Mr Yee Jenn Jong (Non-Constituency Member) : I thank the Minister for the comprehensive answers. What role can Singapore play to mediate to prevent such open conflicts, and how prepared is Singapore, if, unfortunately, such maritime conflicts do take place?

Mr K Shanmugam : Sir, I think China, the claimant states, including the ASEAN countries, recognise that increasing the amount of tension is not in anyone's interests. It is not in China's interest, it is not in the interest of the claimant states, and it is not in the interests of the other countries which are not claimants, because all of us depend on a certain amount of peace and regional harmony to prevail. Among the various parts of the world, in terms of the world economy, the Asia Pacific is a relatively brighter spot today, and it is so because of the free trade flow and the fact that there is not much tension. It is in everyone's interest to maintain that framework. China has publicly said that, and so have ASEAN countries, both claimant and non-claimants, and other powers interested in the region have also said that. I do not think we should probably jump to a conclusion that open conflict would be imminent. If, unfortunately, that scenario does unfold, we have to see how it unfolds. But we in Singapore, like others, will undoubtedly try and reduce the tensions. That is the best answer I can give now.

Mr Speaker : Mr Nicholas Fang, last question.

Mr Nicholas Fang (Nominated Member) : Thank you, Sir, and I thank the Minister again for re-stating Singapore's position on this issue. This issue has illustrated very clearly that the strategic diversity in ASEAN might overwhelm the economic drive towards unity by 2015. Mr K Shanmugam : I do not think strategic diversity by itself may overwhelm the ASEAN Community or move towards greater integration, because there is a substantial economic and strategic logic, towards greater integration within ASEAN. But at the very same time, the economic potential of ASEAN, the fact that there are 600 million people, is an economy of $1.8 trillion, the resources in the region and the resources in the South China Sea, obviously mean that it is an area of interest to powers outside of the immediate region, legitimately so. And it is in this situation that ASEAN needs to try and keep itself whole, maintain neutrality, centrality, so that it is a master of its own destiny. Whether it will remain so depends, of course, on the members, and the forces that may break us apart may well overwhelm us. You cannot discount that possibility. And if it happens, we will have to deal with it.

Conviction of Dr Woffles Wu for Abetment of Giving False Information

11 Ms Sylvia Lim asked the Minister for Law regarding the conviction of Dr Woffles Wu for abetment of giving false information to the police (a) in what manner did Dr Wu abet the giving of false information to the police; (b) whether the Attorney-General's Chambers' statement of 17 June 2012 explaining the choice of charge against Dr Wu has addressed public concerns about the equitability of the legal system; and (c) whether the Ministry has confirmation that written grounds of decision will be given by the sentencing court, despite there being no appeal pending.

12 Asst Prof Tan Kheng Boon Eugene asked the Minister for Law (a) whether, during the course of police investigations into speeding offences involving the car of Dr Woffles Wu in September 2005 and November 2006, information was obtained specifically and directly from Dr Wu and, if not, why not; (b) whether the information provided to the police by the person whom Dr Wu abetted was subjected to appropriate scrutiny in view of the employment relationship between them and, if not, why not; (c) whether the non-prosecution of the person whom Dr Wu abetted creates an exception that may be open to abuse; and (d) why are investigations into the identity of the driver of Dr Wu's car protracted.

The Minister for Law (Mr K Shanmugam) : Sir, with your leave, I will take both questions together Ms Lim's and then Prof Tan's.

Mr Speaker : Yes.

Page: 469

Mr K Shanmugam : Sir, a large part of Ms Lim's question concerns the exercise of prosecutorial discretion. That is within the independent province of the Attorney-General (AG), in his capacity as the Public Prosecutor. I have therefore consulted with the AG in giving this answer.

Ms Lim has asked three questions. I will answer them in turn. First question in what manner did Dr Wu abet the giving of false information to the police? Dr Woffles Wu was the registered owner of a motorcar that was detected travelling at 95 km/h on 11 September 2005 in an area where the speed limit was 70 km/h. The same car was also detected travelling at 91 km/h on 11 November 2006 in an area where the speed limit was 70 km/h. On both occasions, the Traffic Police sent Dr Wu the usual notices and forms, requiring him to furnish the particulars of the person who was driving the car at the time of the traffic offence.

On both occasions, Dr Wu did not fill in the forms provided. Instead, Dr Wu's employee, Mr Kuan Yit Wah, filled in the forms and indicated that he, Mr Kuan, was the driver of the car. The Traffic Police receive many such forms each day, and usually proceed on the basis of the declarations received. Subsequently, information was received by CPIB that the Traffic Police may have been given false declarations. Investigations were then conducted. The investigations showed that false declarations had been made by Mr Kuan at the request of Dr Wu.

Dr Wu pleaded guilty to one count of abetting by instigating Mr Kuan to provide false or misleading information to the Traffic Police. He had abetted a breach of section 81(2) of the Road Traffic Act for the offence in 2006.

A second count of abetment for the earlier occasion was taken into consideration. The district court sentenced him to the maximum fine of $1,000. Mr Kuan was let off with a stern warning because he did not receive any monetary reward, because of his old age and because Dr Wu was considered the more culpable of the two.

Ms Lim next asked whether the Attorney-General's Chambers' statement of 17 June 2012 explaining the choice of charges against Dr Wu has addressed public concerns about the equitability of the legal system. Implicit in Ms Lim's question are, I believe, the following assertions one, that Dr Wu could have been charged for a more serious offence, and two, he was not so charged because he is who he is. There was favouritism.

To answer this, we need to look at how Dr Wu's case was treated, in comparison with other similar cases. I assume Ms Lim has looked at the facts and law carefully. If so, she will know the answer to the questions she raises. Dr Wu was charged under section 81(3) of the Road Traffic Act. If I could have that handed out to Ms Lim, and we will read it today [A h andout was distributed to hon Members]. Can someone just give it to Ms Lim first, please?

If you look at section 81(2), where the driver of a motor vehicle is alleged or is suspected to be guilty of an offence under this Act, any other person who or should have been in charge of the motor vehicle shall, if required by a police officer or employee of the Authority, give any information which it is in his power to give, and which may lead to the identification of the driver, and within seven days of the date on which the information was required from him. If he fails to do so, he shall be guilty of an offence.

Mr Speaker : Minister, the handout that you provided does not have the Act

Sir, I will now reply Asst Prof Tan's questions.

Asst Prof Tan first asked whether information was obtained specifically and directly from Dr Wu during the course of police investigations into speeding offences involving Dr Wu's car in September 2005 and November 2006, and if not, why not.

Dr Wu was not interviewed by the Traffic Police when the traffic violations in 2005 and 2006 were initially investigated. This was consistent with the usual practice. Mr Kuan had signed the relevant forms identifying himself as the driver of the motorcar when the violations were committed. There was no reason for the Traffic Police to suspect that anything was amiss.

Asst Prof Tan next asked whether the information provided to the Police by the person whom Dr Wu abetted was subjected to the appropriate scrutiny in view of the employment relationship between them, and if not, why not.

When a speeding violation is alleged or suspected to have been committed, the owner or the driver of the vehicle in question is only required to disclose the identity, address and driving licence number of the person who drove the vehicle at the material time. The Police will then act on the information provided. The information that was provided by Mr Kuan in relation to the two incidents in 2005 and 2006 were dealt with according to standard procedure.

Regarding Asst Prof Tan's question about Mr Kuan being an employee, it is not a requirement for the driver to disclose his or her relationship with the registered owner of the car. As such, the relationship between Dr Wu and Mr Kuan would not have been flagged out in the first place. Even if the employer/employee relationship between Dr Wu and Mr Kuan had been disclosed, given the fact that Mr Kuan had voluntarily identified himself as the driver of the vehicle on both occasions, there would have been no cogent reason to further scrutinise the information that was provided.

Asst Prof Tan also queries the non-prosecution of Mr Kuan. I think Members know that the Attorney-General's discretion is exercised with reference to a range of factors. Between the elderly Mr Kuan, who had not received any monetary reward, and Dr Wu, it was assessed that Dr Wu was the more culpable of the two. Dr Wu was therefore prosecuted, whereas Mr Kuan was issued with a stern warning, and I think Members will agree with that exercise of discretion.

Page: 474

Finally, Asst Prof Tan asks: why have investigations into the identity of the driver of Dr Wu's car been so protracted? The underlying speeding offences were committed in 2005 and 2006, but the complaint that Dr Wu had procured Mr Kuan to make a false statement was only received by the CPIB much later in July 2009. Due to the personal circumstances of the complainant, which I really do not want to go into, the CPIB was only able to obtain a full statement in February 2010. After the CPIB concluded that no corrupt practices had transpired, investigations were taken over by Traffic Police in August 2010. Whilst investigations into the identity of the driver were ongoing, Prosecution proceeded against Dr Wu for abetting the giving of false information in September 2011. Investigations have been completed on the identity and I understand that AGC will issue a statement on their decision.
