4.37 pm

Mr Desmond Lee (Jurong) : Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to make a few brief comments on five aspects of this Bill. First, about the new offence in clause 29 that specifically targets Marriages of Convenience (MOCs). Previously, people who entered into such arrangements were prosecuted under the Prevention of Corruption Act. This attracted a maximum fine of up to $100,000, or imprisonment of up to five years, or both.

Subsequently, when these were prosecuted under the offence of giving false information under section 57(1)(k) of the Immigration Act the deterrent effect was substantially diminished as the maximum penalty is a fine of up to $4,000, or imprisonment of up to 12 months, or both.

Page: 496

The new offence in clause 29 recalibrates the deterrent impact as it attracts a maximum fine of $10,000, or jail of up to 10 years, or both. This is appropriate for three reasons: first, MOCs are not easy to detect, as they may involve many intricate layers of deception; second, the act of deceiving immigration authorities is a very serious matter, as it can jeopardise public security. It should therefore be seriously punished; and, third, in the worst sorts of cases, MOCs may even be arranged by, or involve transnational organised crime and people trafficking.

In fact, I would recommend that clause 29 be reviewed so that the maximum fine where human trafficking and exploitation is involved, is significantly high, say, for instance, $100,000. I would also like to ask if the Minister can share with us why, instead of creating this new offence, the prosecution does not continue to prosecute such offences under the Prevention of Corruption Act (PCA) like it did in the past. Is it because the PCA is not sufficiently specific or sufficiently wide enough to cover such cases?

I would further suggest that, like in the PCA, the Attorney-General's written consent be obtained and furnished to the Court before a charge under this new MOC offence can be pursued in Court. This will act as a safeguard, as investigations into MOC offences are necessarily intrusive and potentially traumatic for genuine couples. Also, when a marriage breaks down, false allegations could be made in the heat of the moment.

My next comment is on clause 8, which amends section 11 of the Act to empower ICA to impose conditions on PRs applying for Re-Entry Permits. Interestingly, the term "Permanent Resident" does not seem to appear anywhere in the Immigration Act.

The Minister earlier shared that ICA will be imposing conditions that effectively widen the circumstances under which a PR's Re-Entry Permit may be revoked. Currently, it can only be revoked if the holder commits a serious offence and is imprisoned as a result.

While I welcome giving ICA greater flexibility to impose proportionate and sensible conditions on PRs, I would urge the Government to continue to exercise this power judiciously and compassionately. For instance, Entry and Re-Entry Permits for PRs should be revoked only if a serious offence is committed. This is because many PRs are spouses, parents or children of Singapore citizens, or have lived many years in Singapore and contributed and assimilated into our community. While we expect them to obey the law like everyone else, they, like everyone else, are not infallible. In particular, we should try our best to ensure that families comprising both Singaporeans and PRs are not needlessly split up as a result.

My third set of comments relate to clauses 11 and 13, which require passenger and crew information to be furnished in advance of the arrival of aircraft and vessels in Singapore, if so required by ICA. These amendments will go some way in further strengthening Singapore's border control and counter-terrorism efforts and allow ICA to more effectively screen passenger arrivals for security risks. This is enhanced by clause 23, which amends section 36B to now allow ICA to share identifiable information, including biometric data about people for counter-terrorism purposes.

This move is timely as many other countries already require the submission of advance passenger information. For instance, US Customs and Border Protection implemented its Advance Passenger Information (API) System some years ago.

Page: 497

However, I have two queries for the Minister: first, airlines and passenger vessels operate across many jurisdictions. Some countries, especially in the European Union, have very strict data protection legislation, which may prohibit the disclosure of passenger information or personal identifiable information, except under certain circumstances or if sufficient safeguards are demonstrated. What would ICA do if these foreign laws prohibit airlines or passenger vessels from complying or fully complying with our own requirements under clauses 11 and 13? How would ICA help these companies that operate across the world resolve these cross-jurisdiction dilemmas.

Second, I would like to ask the Minister, to what extent does this new system aid in the management of international public health risks. I recall, sometime in 2007, a man suffering from extremely drug resistant tuberculosis (XDR-TB) had caused an international public health scare when he took two trans-Atlantic flights one from the US to Europe and another from Europe back to Canada when he had been told specifically that he should not travel. Supposing in future our Ministry of Health receives intelligence about such a risk, would the Immigration Act, as amended, allow ICA to share Advance Passenger Information with Public Health Officers so that appropriate public health measures can be instituted to protect Singaporeans? I note that under the Infectious Diseases Act, no API power exists.

My fourth comment is about the amendments in clauses 3 and 4 that allow ICA to declare certain places as temporary immigration checkpoints and to impose requirements on owners of such places. The Minister mentioned private marinas and Yacht Clubs. While I accept that illegal landings can take place anywhere along our coastline, I am nevertheless concerned that these private checkpoints, such as jetties and landing berths, may pose security risks. For instance, their legitimacy may provide cover for illicit smuggling of contraband, drugs or firearms. Can the Minister share with us what steps ICA will take to ensure that security at these checkpoints is as stringent as our own regular checkpoints and international passenger terminals?

Finally, I would like to express my strong support for clause 6 of the Bill, which amends the Immigration Act to remove persons suffering from mental disorder from the list of prohibited immigrants. Apart from complying with the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, which we understand the Government intends to ratify soon, this gesture also goes some way towards reducing the stigma faced by people suffering from mental disability. This is a step in the right direction. With that, Sir, I support the Bill.

4.46 pm

Mr S Iswaran : Mr Speaker, Sir, I thank all the Members who have spoken, and I also appreciate their support for the Bill and the policy intent that underpins it. Several Members have commented on our immigration policies in general. Though that is not directly within the ambit of this Bill, it is important that this House acknowledges the genuine concerns of Singaporeans over immigration policies and strategies. Our immigration policies must be responsive to our social and economic circumstances and needs.

Page: 498

As Members would be aware, over the last few years, we have tightened our immigration framework and put in place more stringent controls on foreign workforce inflow and the grant of PRs and citizenship. This entails choices and trade-offs that we have to make as a society, and these are also outlined in the recent paper, "Our Population, Our Future", just released by the National Population and Talent Division, that aims to foster a national dialogue and consensus on this important and complex issue. I would urge Members and, indeed, all Singaporeans, to participate actively in this process. Our aim, ultimately, is to have a sustainable population strategy that strengthens social cohesion, ensures a good living environment that maintains our economic vitality.

Let me now turn to the points that have been raised by Members on specific aspects of the Bill. First, on Assoc Prof Fatimah Lateef's question pertaining to Advance Passenger Information. Indeed, Advance Passenger Information will allow ICA to do early pre-screening of arriving passengers, assess the security risks of the passengers and determine the appropriate course of action against those assessed to be of security risks to Singapore. These actions would include additional security screening prior to entry and denial of entry into Singapore if the risks are assessed to be significant.

I agree with Mr Patrick Tay and Mr Teo Siong Seng that Advance Passenger Information is a pre-emptive measure and will help to strengthen Singapore's border security. With this, ICA will have more lead time a point that Ms Sylvia Lim made as well to plan in advance the appropriate course of action to be taken against individuals who might pose a risk to us.

Sir, Mr Desmond Lee spoke about the conflicting situations that some airlines may face if data security laws in their country prohibit disclosure of passenger information. ICA will be working closely with the airlines to implement the Advance Passenger Information regime. As many other countries have already implemented the system, international airlines are generally familiar with the requirements. To address data security law requirements, some international carriers make it known to their passengers on the airline websites and on their tickets and documents that they are legally required to provide Advance Passenger Information to the authorities when travelling to certain countries.

Mr Desmond Lee also asked whether, with the amendment of the Immigration Act, ICA could share the Advance Passenger Information (API) with the Ministry of Health. At this juncture, the API regime is not intended directly to be used to collect travellers' medical information, but one cannot rule that out in the future. The ICA will continue to share information which it has obtained to the extent that is permitted by law, and that includes situations where it is in the public interest to do so. The example he cited was a case in point in that regard.

Let me now turn to imposing security requirements for private operators at authorised areas. Mr Desmond Lee asked about the steps that the Ministry or ICA will take to ensure that small temporary entry points do not pose security risks. Ms Sylvia Lim had a more fundamental question of who and why. First, let me be clear that we do not approve such checkpoints lightly to be an authorised point of entry and departure. We only do so when there is a specific application and it must come from a credible source which provides immigration facilities to Singaporeans, Permanent Residents and foreigners. They must also have a sufficiently high traffic volume to justify the provision of dedicated immigration facilities. In addition, they must also meet our security and immigration function requirements. Indeed, it is precisely to ensure that there are no security breaches that this amendment is being proposed so that all our checkpoints have sufficiently robust security control systems. The proposed amendment will give ICA the necessary powers to ensure that authorised immigration areas in private establishments, such as marinas, meet all the necessary security and immigration functional requirements at all times.

Page: 499

Ms Sylvia Lim asked why the Government does not subsidise this cost since we have assessed it to be necessary to impose such requirements. The question of subsidy does not arise simply because this is at the request of these private operators and, if it is assessed that they meet a certain minimum threshold to justify such provision, then they will have to comply with the security and immigration provision requirements and, quite naturally, have to then bear the costs that are consequential. ICA will not hesitate to take action against those who do not meet the stringent standards. The proposed amendments will allow us, as I have stated earlier, to impose a fine of not less than $100,000 and not more than $200,000. I think these penalties are sufficiently serious to ensure that those who apply for such facilities take it seriously as well.

Mr Desmond Lee has also asked about the steps that ICA can take to ensure that coastal establishments, such as jetties and landing berths, do not pose any security risks. The ICA works closely with the Police Coast Guard to conduct regular checks and surprise security spot checks on these coastal establishments to ensure that there are no security breaches.

Mr Speaker, Sir, let me now turn to the somewhat delicate and nettlesome topic of marriages of conveniences. The Members who have spoken have given quite strong views. On the one hand, there is a desire for rigorous enforcement of those that are egregious, clear cases of marriages of convenience (MOC), yet we want to be sure that we do not unfairly penalise genuine marriages, and take into account some of the changing norms in our society.

Let me start with some data. Members asked what the trend is. Over the last five years, we have detected an average of about four or five MOC cases a year, which does not sound like a lot. But as Mr Hri Kumar pointed out in his speech, it is also a case of how such cases come to light, the manner of the investigation and the manner of the evidence being procured. But even in that context, for the first six months of this year, we have detected 12 MOC cases. So there is a significant rise, and it is probably symptomatic of a larger trend. We want to introduce new laws to send a strong deterrent message to individuals who contemplate entering into marriages of convenience for the purpose of obtaining an immigration facility, such as PR, Long-Term Visit Passes and Entry Visa.

Mr Hri Kumar asked whether this should apply to PRs as well, and the answer is "yes" because, technically, a Permanent Resident comprises the Entry Permit and that is what the Act applies towards. So, once it affects the Entry Permits or Re-entry Permits, then, effectively, it affects Permanent Residents. For citizens, it is different. It comes under the Constitution. But anyone applying for citizenship would usually have to go through a progression through Visit Passes and Permanent Residents before they get to that stage.

Page: 500

Assoc Prof Fatimah Lateef raised the issue of middlemen and brokers of marriages of convenience. Ms Tin Pei Ling also brought up the exposure of a sham marriage ring in 2010. We want to take a tough stance against any intermediary who facilitates a marriage of convenience. With this Bill, there will be explicit provisions allowing ICA to prosecute these middlemen and agents.

Members have also spoken about the need to be fair to genuine marriages and the need for due diligence and thorough investigations. I want to assure Members that this will certainly be done and that is, indeed, the intent of ICA. ICA will conduct thorough background checks before going into full-blown investigations and proceed to take action only when there is sufficient evidence that the marriage is one of convenience. ICA will work closely with the Ministry of Manpower, the Ministry of Community Development, Youth and Sports, and the Registry of Marriages to investigate suspicious cases.

Mr Hri Kumar, Asst Prof Eugene Tan and Ms Sylvia Lim also asked the question whether the evidentiary tests are being set too high by requiring gratification to be proven. I want to explain to Members how we are approaching this. We are creating a new criminal offence. We want to be careful about it and we thought it would be prudent to therefore have not just subjective criteria but also an objective test to ensure that when action is indeed taken, there are good grounds to proceed. If we did not have the objective tests, then, in fact, we could say all marriages are potentially investigable. On balance, we thought this would be the right way to proceed. I concede that it does impose a higher burden of proof on the prosecution and on the enforcement agencies, but we think that this is the right way to go and we should assess this in practice before we see whether there is a need for any further change.

The point was also raised about traditional marriages where dowries are exchanged but the two parties involved may not have known each other. I think Asst Prof Eugene Tan raised the example of foreign brides and so on.

I want to go back to a point which I have made earlier in the Second Reading speech but also raised in the discussion. The facts that govern whether a marriage is one of convenience cannot be confined to just what occurs at the point of marriage but it is also an ex poste determination. So, we have to look at the facts after the point of marriage as well. We could have a couple who are in an arranged marriage, so they may be strangers, but they may have a genuine intent. Then the question before the courts and, indeed, the enforcement agencies, would be, "What is the evidence of their true intent after the point of marriage?" These will all be taken into account. So the totality of the facts surrounding the marriage would be a key consideration in determining whether it is indeed a marriage of convenience. And so, gratification, whilst it is necessary, is not a sufficient condition of proof.

Mr Desmond Lee made the point about the risk of false allegations and he wanted to know what we can do in order to deter this. First, I want to assure him that ICA will do its thorough background checks precisely because we do not want frivolous complaints. We will take care to ensure that the person is not the unwitting victim of a malicious complaint. Under section 182 of the Penal Code, the authorities can take legal action against any person who knowingly provides false information to allege that a genuine marriage is a marriage of convenience and cause injury or annoyance to an innocent party.

Page: 501

Mr Lee has also asked why the prosecution does not continue to prosecute marriages of convenience under the Prevention of Corruption Act. There were legal impediments to charge marriage of convenience cases under the Prevention of Corruption Act primarily because you cannot always prove corruption in the context of a marriage of convenience, which is why this amendment provides for a specific offence under the Immigration Act.

Mr Lee has suggested that ICA seeks the prosecutor's consent before prosecution can take place. There are existing standard operating procedures for ICA to refer cases to the prosecutor and, for complex cases, such as these, in marriages of convenience, after ICA conducts the investigation, the facts of the case will be forwarded to the prosecutor. I would like to assure Members that for the MOC cases, ICA will seek the concurrence of the prosecutor on the course of action to be taken.

Let me turn to the Good Conduct condition on Re-entry Permits. Let me explain once again that a foreigner who wishes to reside in Singapore permanently may apply for an Entry Permit which confers the PR status on him and then he needs a Re-entry Permit to be able to travel out and back into Singapore. These are the two elements that come together. There is currently a Good Conduct condition in Entry Permits issued to PRs. It states that Entry Permits may be cancelled if the holder contravenes any law or is involved in any activity which threatens a breach of peace or is prejudicial to public order or public welfare. This amendment will harmonise the Good Conduct condition on the Entry Permit with that on the Re-entry Permit as well. The proposed amendment offers greater calibration of responses when Permanent Residents contravene the law or are involved in activities that are prejudicial to public order.

Currently, in cases of serious offences where a jail term has been imposed, we may revoke a foreigner's PR status by declaring him as a prohibited immigrant. And this has consequences beyond just revocation of the PR because it also effectively bans him or her from re-entry into Singapore unless they seek specific permission. With these changes, it gives ICA a wider range of actions to deal with errant Permanent Residents. For relatively minor offences, ICA has always exercised its discretion by issuing warnings as another option.

This goes to the point raised by Mr Hri Kumar. So, rather than define a minimum fine threshold before specific action can be taken, the enforcement agencies today, even without this amendment, have already been exercising discretion, and there is a wider spectrum of options now available to them if this Bill is passed, from warnings to revocation of the Entry Permits and Re-entry Permits to designating them as prohibited immigrants. There is a spectrum of options and this is to allow our enforcement agencies greater flexibility to calibrate their response.

Sir, I want to assure Members that ICA will carefully consider the facts and circumstances of each case, including the nature and type of offence, the severity of the offence and the PR's local family ties before revoking a person's PR status.

Mr Hri Kumar raised the issue and then answered it as well so I thank him for that about whether the ambit is too wide. As he said, and I am happy to emphasise, I want to assure the House that the provision will not be used liberally. It will be exercised judiciously and the impact will really be on a very small proportion of those who are minded to flout our laws. There will be due process and safeguards to ensure that the immigration permits of Permanent Residents are not cancelled arbitrarily. The Controller of Immigration will notify the PR in writing that we intend to cancel his permits and the grounds for doing so. The PR can then appeal against this decision. If the appeal is not successful and eventually the immigration permits are cancelled, aggrieved persons can appeal against the cancellation to the Minister for Home Affairs. This would address Asst Prof Eugene Tan's point about the right to be heard.

Page: 502

Let me finally address the point raised by Mr Teo Siong Seng. He has expressed a view from the point of view of the industry, to know whether there is an excessive burden on merchant ships who rescued persons in the high seas on humanitarian grounds. They may not have documents or they may not be sure of their status. I want to stress that we are sympathetic to genuine cases of distress and will not take action against these ship owners who render the necessary humanitarian assistance, or the persons in distress. To go further, ICA will work closely with their local Embassy representatives to facilitate genuine persons in distress with the proper documentation and eventual return to their home country. However, I want to highlight that there are criminal syndicates who fabricate distress as a means to secure landing. We want to make sure that we maintain a tough stance against such intended violations. On balance, the merchant shippers will have to bear this in mind and there is a balance of risks and not unlike, for example, passengers who come on aircraft, there is an obligation on the carrier to repatriate if there is, in fact, an immigration violation which they have not picked up in their due diligence.

Mr Hri Kumar also asked the question, and this is in the context of the marriages of convenience, if there is a long period of investigation and which leads to enforcement, what would be the status of the individual or individuals in the interim period. Given that they are innocent until proven guilty, they will be allowed to stay in Singapore until a charge is made and a conviction is secured.

Mr Speaker, Sir, I have substantively addressed the main issues raised by Members. I want to emphasise that our efforts to combat immigration-related offences have led to a decrease in the number of immigration offenders from 7,700 immigration offenders arrested in 2007 to 3,100 immigration offenders arrested last year. But we must not let our guard down and this Bill will strengthen our ability to protect and secure our borders and help us better maintain law and order in a new security environment. May I urge Members of the House to give your support to the Immigration (Amendment) Bill.

Ms Sylvia Lim : Sir, I would like to ask the Minister for clarification concerning the exclusive clearance provisions. I wonder if he can explain to the House whether the Ministry has any indication of the likely demand for these special checkpoints. There must be a reason why these amendments are being proposed. How many more such checkpoints can we expect and is there a critical caseload we are looking at? I think he also did not address my query about ICA resources and whether additional manpower is needed or it will actually take away people from the ordinary checkpoints.

Mr S Iswaran : Mr Speaker, Sir, we are not moving this Bill because we anticipate a deluge of such applications. Actually, the primary motivation is to be able to impose specific security and other compliance requirements on any entity that is minded to apply for such a facility. I want to be very clear about that. Secondly, the question of ICA resources does not arise per se because we are imposing the burden of the cost on the entity that applies. So, if an application is received and it is deemed to be meritorious and the facility is approved, then there will be an obligation on the entity's part to meet all our security requirements and to pay for the cost of any immigration resources that are deployed there as well. And then Immigration (ICA) would have to recruit the appropriate staffing to meet the challenges there.

The House immediately resolved itself into a Committee on the Bill. [Mr S Iswaran].

Written Answers to Questions for Oral Answer Not Answered by 3.00 pm

Page: 504

Ensuring Quality Early Childhood Education and Childcare Services

17 Ms Low Yen Ling asked the Acting Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports for 2011, (a) what is the amount of Government spending, as a percentage of the GDP, on early childhood education in Singapore in the areas of (i) childcare services; (ii) kindergartens; (iii) provision for Baby Bonus Scheme; and (iv) subsidies, training and scholarships for the early childhood education profession; and (b) what is the amount spent on assistance for disadvantaged pre-schoolers in early childhood education.

18 Er Dr Lee Bee Wah asked the Acting Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports following the announcement to build about 200 more childcare centres by 2018 (a) in which wards will the first batch of these centres be built; (b) whether this addition of 200 childcare centres is sufficient to meet the growing demand; (c) what are the plans to ensure that there will be sufficient qualified childcare teachers in these centres; and (d) what are the steps taken to make these childcare centres more affordable.

19 Er Dr Lee Bee Wah asked the Acting Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports whether the Ministry will consider collaborating with the private sector to set up subsidised childcare centres in the vicinity of organisations with employees exceeding 200 in strength.

20 Miss Penny Low asked the Acting Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports (a) whether there is a shortage of childcare places especially in new towns; (b) if so, what is the nature of the shortage and what measures are in place to address this shortage in the short term.

21 Dr Lim Wee Kiak asked the Acting Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports (a) what is the current number of childcare centres and how many qualified early childhood educators are there in Singapore; and (b) whether there is a shortage of these educators and, if so, what measures are in place to address this shortage.

22 Mr Alex Yam asked the Acting Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports (a) how many childcare centres have been set up in (i) the financial district; and (ii) industrial districts; and (b) whether the Ministry will consider providing further incentives to developers to set aside building space for not-for-profit operators to run childcare centres.

23 Mr Yee Jenn Jong asked the Acting Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports (a) how many childcare centres are currently operated by for-profit private operators at (i) HDB void decks and places managed by JTC Corporation; and (ii) restructured hospitals and buildings owned by the Government and statutory boards; (b) what are the average monthly rents paid by these operators in these respective areas; and (c) of the 200 new childcare centres to be built by 2018, how many of them will be situated at HDB void decks and places managed by JTC Corporation and what is the planned allocation of these centres between not-for-profit and for-profit organisations.

Page: 505

Mr Chan Chun Sing : I would like to thank the hon Members for their interest and suggestions on childcare services.

Miss Penny Low and Er Dr Lee Bee Wah have asked whether the Government's effort to expand capacity is sufficient to meet growing demand. Today, we have 987 childcare centres providing close to 90,000 places for infant and childcare. There are also 498 kindergartens that provide another 93,000 places for children between the ages of four to six. The overall utilisation rate of childcare places stands at 84%.

However, in some estates such as Punggol, Jurong West and Woodlands, there is a higher proportion of families with young children. Parents in these estates may encounter difficulties in enrolling their children in their preferred centres. My Ministry has been focusing our efforts on increasing the number of childcare centres in these high demand estates. In Punggol, for example, 20 new centres are being developed, including 10 which will be ready by the end of this year.

The availability of suitable sites is a constraint on our ability to expand more quickly. We have yet to identify all 200 sites we intend to set aside for new childcare centres from 2013 to 2018. My Ministry is working closely with HDB to identify the new sites, especially in estates with high demand and in new townships. Given the numbers required, we will have to explore the use of other spaces, beyond HDB void decks, such as community centres, sports complexes, office buildings, retail malls and vacant state buildings for setting up childcare centres. The sites available for tender by both non-profit and private childcare centres are progressively made known on MCYS' Child Care Link website.

In determining the allocation of sites for non-profit centres and for-profit centres, MCYS takes into account the resident and housing type profiles, current mix of centres and views of the community and community leaders. For HDB void deck sites, our primary consideration is to ensure that such sites are used to provide affordable childcare options. Mr Yee Jenn Jong asked about the number of for-profit childcare centres in HDB void decks and state buildings. There are currently 176 centres run by for-profits in HDB void decks which make up about 37% of all HDB void deck centres. There are another 52 centres in Government buildings, including hospitals. Private operators on such sites pay market rentals which vary from site to site.

Mr Alex Yam and Er Dr Lee Bee Wah suggested expanding the number of workplace childcare centres. Today, there are 22 childcare centres located in the central business district and 241 centres located in commercial premises, Government or other buildings. These centres make up about 27% of all centres and cater to parents who prefer a centre in the vicinity of their workplace.

The Government currently provides grants to organisations and developers that are keen to set up workplace childcare centres. We provide capital grants for the purchase of furnishings and equipment for the centre as well as development grants for centres set up in Government buildings.

Private commercial developers can also tap on URA's Community and Sports Facilities Scheme. Developers receive additional gross floor area (GFA) of up to 3,000 square metres of retail space by integrating community facilities run by not-for-profit organisations in their development. Childcare is one of the approved uses under the scheme.

Page: 506

We agree more can be done to encourage the development of workplace childcare centres. We welcome suggestions raised by Members in our on-going policy review.

In the area of quality, some Members have asked if there are sufficient qualified early childhood educators. There are currently about 11,000 childcare teachers, educarers and centre supervisors in the sector. More than 90% of childcare teachers for the four to six age group are diploma trained or undergoing the Diploma in Early Childhood.

My Ministry works closely with various partners to attract, develop and retain teachers and other personnel for the sector. For example, we work with the Workforce Development Agency (WDA) and training providers to develop a pipeline of new and qualified teachers. This year, WDA will appoint two more training agencies as programme partners, increasing the training capacity for the sector. The Government also offers scholarships in early childhood studies for both new and existing teachers. We recently introduced a Good Employers toolkit and conducted workshops on good human resource practices in the sector to improve staff retention.

We have made some progress. About 3,500 new teachers joined the sector in 2011, increasing total manpower by 25%. In the same year, the attrition rate fell from 15% to 13%. We will continue to monitor the manpower situation closely.

Er Dr Lee Bee Wah has asked how the Government seeks to ensure that childcare remains affordable for families. The Government supports parents through various subsidies to defray the cost of childcare. We provide a full day universal childcare subsidy for working mothers of up to $300 per month and infant care subsidy of up to $600 per month per child. Parents can also utilise funds from the Child Development Account (CDA) under the Baby Bonus Scheme to offset the cost of childcare fees. There are also financial assistance schemes under ComCare for childcare for families with household income of up to $3,500, or per capita income of $875 and below.

Ms Low Yen Ling asked about the Government's spending on the pre-school sector. In the financial year 2011, a total of $606.8 million was spent on childcare services, kindergartens, the Baby Bonus Scheme and other measures to support the development of the early childhood sector. This is about 0.19% of our GDP. In the same year, MCYS spent $28.9 million in kindergarten and childcare subsidies under ComCare for pre-schoolers from lower income families. We have also spent $10.3 million to support pre-schoolers with special needs.

Pre-school Education

24 Ms Low Yen Ling asked the Minister for Education whether the Ministry will (i) review the merits and demerits of the Ministry being the lead Ministry for pre-school education, as compared to the present status of the Ministry of Community Development, Youth and Sports overseeing childcare services and the Ministry looking after kindergartens; (ii) evaluate and address the risks of over-teaching in kindergartens as teachers and parents prepare children for Primary 1 in the absence of detailed guidelines on the level of academic and overall competence required for entry into P1; and (iii) consider offering subsidies to working mothers of children studying in kindergartens like how subsidies are given to working mothers of children in childcare services.

Page: 507

25 Mr Lim Biow Chuan asked the Minister for Education (a) whether the Government will consider taking over the management and operation of pre-schools, kindergartens and childcare centres; and (b) what are the implications of such a decision.

26 Mr Ang Hin Kee asked the Minister for Education whether the Ministry will respond to the concerns raised on the state of pre-school education in Singapore and recommendations made by the study commissioned by the Lien Foundation.

27 Mr Laurence Lien asked the Minister for Education in light of Singapore's ranking of 29th out of 45 countries in the recent global survey on early childhood education conducted by the Economist Intelligence Unit, whether there are plans to review the availability, affordability and quality of early childhood education in Singapore.

Mr Heng Swee Keat : MOE recognises the importance of pre-school education. A major review of pre-school education was conducted in 2008 by the MOE-MCYS Joint Steering Committee. Arising from the review, we have taken steps to improve the quality, affordability and accessibility of pre-school education in Singapore.

We are raising quality through a three-pronged strategy of raising teacher quality, programme quality and centre quality.

First, to improve teacher quality, MOE and MCYS raised the minimum professional and academic qualifications required of pre-school teachers. From January 2009, all new pre-school teachers will need to have a minimum of 5 GCE "O" level credits and a minimum professional qualification of a Diploma in Early Childhood Care and Education Teaching. We have also invested in the professional development of our pre-school teachers through various bursaries, scholarships and teaching awards, and provided subsidised training for continuing professional development.

Second, MOE is strengthening programme quality by developing and disseminating curriculum resources to all pre-schools. We are currently updating our Kindergarten Curriculum Framework and will distribute the revised framework to all pre-schools by the second half of 2012. Additionally, both MOE and MCYS extend funding support to pre-schools, such as the Innovation Grant to encourage a culture of innovation in the delivery of programmes. The two Ministries also regularly organise professional sharing platforms such as the Kindergarten Conference, the Kindergarten Learning Forum, and Child Care Seminar to promote professional development and sharing of best practices.

Third, MOE is raising centre quality through the Singapore Pre-school Accreditation Framework (SPARK), implemented in 2011 to support pre-schools in their efforts to improve the teaching and learning, administration and management processes. SPARK drives continuous improvement and provides an indicator of quality for parents making choices on pre-school. So far, 115 pre-schools have received the SPARK certification.

To ensure that pre-school education remains affordable, the Government has made available a range of subsidies, including universal childcare subsidies and additional financial assistance for children from lower income families. The eligible income criterion for ComCare childcare and kindergarten subsidies was revised upwards from $1,800 to $3,500 with effect from 1 April 2011. As a result, the number of beneficiaries has increased by 25%. Ms Low Yen Ling would be glad to note that these subsidies apply regardless of whether a child attends kindergarten or childcare, and ensures no child is denied access to pre-school because of his family's financial circumstances.

Page: 508

MOE and MCYS will continue to look into the issue of affordability of pre-school education, and consider if the current range of subsidies is adequate.

While we have not made pre-school compulsory, the access to pre-school education is very high 99% of our recent P1 cohort attended at least one year of pre-school. This is higher than some countries where pre-school is compulsory. We have achieved this through a dedicated focus of reaching out to children not enrolled in pre-school. An inter-agency committee, helmed by MOE with representatives from MCYS, People's Association and PCF Headquarters, identifies and reaches out to children not attending pre-school. We are also assisted by grassroots leaders and social workers who visit needy families, and assist their children with pre-school enrolment.

The early years are crucial for a child's holistic development and for laying a strong foundation for lifelong learning.

While MOE does not prescribe a curriculum for pre-schools, teaching and learning in pre-schools are guided by MOE's Kindergarten Curriculum Framework and Guide in Designing programmes that are developmentally appropriate for children aged four to six.

As Ms Low Yen Ling pointed out, parents are naturally concerned about their child's readiness for primary school. However, developmental and education experts warn against "over-teaching" pre-school children and the potential detrimental impact on the child. Such an approach ignores the spectrum of potential and pace of development which exists normally in children of pre-school ages and should be discouraged.

MOE is currently refreshing the Kindergarten Curriculum Framework to take into account recent research findings in child development and will also articulate the core competencies a child should possess, such as in the areas of Language and Literacy and Numeracy, at the end of pre-school education and as they enter primary school. The refreshed framework will be disseminated to all pre-schools, and made available to the public by the end of this year.

MOE and MCYS work closely on policies and practices for the pre-school sector, to raise the quality of the pre-school sector and to enhance the professional development of pre-school educators. For example, SPARK applies to both kindergartens and childcare centres. Similarly, professional qualification requirements and professional development routes developed by MOE apply to both kindergarten and childcare teachers. We thank Member Low Yen Ling for her suggestion for MOE to be the lead Ministry for the pre-school sector. MOE and MCYS will study how best the Government can oversee and support the sector.

More can be done, including in the other areas of improvement highlighted by the studies commissioned by the Lien Foundation, which both Mr Laurence Lien and Mr Ang Hin Kee referred to. The studies are timely and add to the feedback we have been gathering. The Government will consolidate and study all feedback carefully, and see what further measures are needed to raise the quality of pre-school education.

Impact of Changes in Minimum Salaries

30 Mr Zaqy Mohamad asked the Acting Minister for Manpower (a) what is the Ministry's assessment of the impact of the changes in minimum salaries on foreign workers and businesses; (b) which are the sectors most affected by this change; (c) what proportion of foreign workers have been given a wage increase that is more than the National Wages Council's recommended increase upon renewal of their contracts; (d) whether this measure has resulted in an increase or decrease in foreign manpower since it was implemented; and (e) how have Singaporean wages improved since the implementation of this measure.

Mr Tan Chuan-Jin : The Government does not prescribe any minimum salary or salary increase for foreign workers.

This is how the system works. Foreigners can come in on Work Permit, S Pass and Employment Pass (EP). There is a range of criteria that they must meet before being eligible. We have essentially tightened up the EP and S Pass salary criteria in July 2011, followed by more tightening in January 2012. What it means is that to be able to bring in foreigners, you must be prepared to pay more for their services, rather than pay a lesser amount at the previous levels. We have also tightened up the qualifications criteria. This protects our Singaporean core because it would make it harder for foreigners to come in at significantly lower wages. It recognises the rising qualities of our local workforce and it is the right direction to go. The age factor has also been worked into the EP framework older applicants would have to command higher salaries to qualify, commensurate with the work experience and quality they are expected to bring. This would help ensure that we would not disadvantage our older Singaporeans. We have provided a transition period for existing EP and S Pass holders, so that businesses can have time to adjust to the changes.

This is not the same as prescribing a minimum salary for foreigners, because companies can choose to recruit a Singaporean instead, or bring the foreigner in on a lower work pass, such as a Work Permit, for which there is no qualifying salary requirement, but subject to the usual dependency ratio ceilings and levies. We also encourage businesses to leverage on the many Government support schemes to raise productivity and reduce dependency on labour over time.

The full impact of these foreign manpower policy changes can only be seen over a longer period of time, especially as some of them have just been implemented. Nevertheless, there are encouraging signs that the tightening measures have had an effect in moderating demand for foreign manpower. Many businesses and organisations across all sectors have provided feedback to me that the tighter policies are constraining their business growth. While they may not like it, I am glad that many also understand that we cannot grow our foreign manpower population indefinitely, have accepted this reality and are proactively adjusting their businesses to embrace the change. And the Government will support our businesses, especially our SMEs, fully to make this transition.

It is still too early to definitively determine the effect of these policy changes on local wages. Preliminary results will be available when the 2012 annual wage change data is published next year. We are tracking the impact of our policies closely.

Page: 510

Lowering of Minimum Household Income Threshold for Lower Rental Rates in HDB's Public Rental Scheme

31 Mr Zainal Sapari asked the Minister for National Development whether HDB will revise the minimum household income from below $800 to below $1,000 for tenants to be eligible for the first-tier rental rates under HDB's Public Rental Scheme for HDB flats in their first and second rental renewals.

Mr Khaw Boon Wan : Public rental flats are intended for low-income households who have no other housing options and family support. The $800 income threshold covers the lowest 12% income households and is not inappropriate. Among the current HDB rental households, 70% of them belong to this tier.

We therefore have no plan to raise the income threshold. However, we do exercise flexibility and waive the rent increase to help those in financial difficulties, including those whose income has increased marginally.

Accident at Worksite at Bugis Station, Downtown Line

(Lessons from Nicoll Highway collapse during Circle Line construction adapted for all construction projects)

32 Mr Gerald Giam Yean Song asked the Minister for Transport whether the lessons learnt from the Nicoll Highway collapse during the construction of the Circle Line in 2004 had been implemented in the Downtown Line construction project, and if these could have prevented the accident on 18 July 2012 that claimed the lives of two workers.

Mr Lui Tuck Yew : I thank the Member for his question. First, let me emphasise that the nature and scale of the two incidents are different. The Nicoll Highway collapse resulted from the failure of the temporary Earth Retaining or Stabilising System (ERSS) for deep excavation works. This led to the collapse of reinforced concrete walls within an excavated area. The Downtown Line (DTL) incident on 18 July, while no less unfortunate, resulted from a temporary scaffolding structure giving way. The incident was localised within the DTL Bugis station site and did not involve deep excavation works.

Following the Nicoll Highway incident, the following key recommendations were adopted for all LTA projects involving underground construction, including the DTL project:

(i) As the developer, LTA would engage an independent Qualified Person(QP) (Supervision) to supervise the construction work;

(ii) LTA would engage an independent checking engineer to check and endorse the ERSS design for deep excavation works; and

(iii) LTA would engage an independent instrumentation specialist firm to supply, install and monitor the instrumentation during the construction work for excavation that exceeds six metres in depth.

Page: 511

Of the above, the recommendation that would be relevant to the Bugis incident is the appointment of the independent QP(Supervision) to supervise the construction work. This was fulfilled.

For temporary scaffolding structures, such as those involved in the Bugis incident, the Contractor is required under the Workplace Safety and Health Act, to engage a Professional Engineer (PE) to design and supervise such works. The legislation also places responsibility on the Contractor and his appointed PE to ensure that the temporary scaffolding structures are safely constructed according to the approved design.

While it is not a statutory requirement for the appointed independent QP(Supervision) to check temporary scaffolding works, LTA had earlier further strengthened its safety framework by imposing a contractual obligation on the QP(Supervision) to also review the design of temporary scaffolding structures by the Contractor's PE. This was implemented for the DTL Bugis station project.

As MOM's formal investigation into the incident is ongoing, it would not be right for me to comment at this juncture, on whether the incident was preventable.

Page: 511

Review of Vehicle Quota System Given Swings in COE Prices

33 Mr Laurence Lien asked the Minister for Transport whether the vehicle quota system needs a fundamental review in light of it producing large swings in the COE quotas and COE prices over the past decade.

Mr Lui Tuck Yew : The Vehicle Quota System (VQS) allows us to manage the growth of our vehicle population in a sustainable manner, and within these parameters, uses market forces to determine the cost of owning a car in Singapore. Since the VQS was introduced in 1990, we have made several refinements to the methodology for determining the COE supply. In particular, we have made changes to determine the supply of replacement COEs for vehicles that have been de-registered, which is the main source of the large swings in COE quotas.

Before 1999, the replacement COEs were determined based on the preceding year's vehicle de-registrations. However, this was felt to be not sufficiently responsive, and a fine-tuning was made in 1999, by projecting vehicle de-registrations for the year ahead using past de-registration trends. This revised methodology was adopted between 1999 and 2010, but it was found to be inherently challenging to make accurate projections, and we ended up with vehicle population growth rates that were well off the targeted growth rates. For example, we had growth rates ranging from -0.2% to 6.6%, instead of the targeted 3% from 1999 to 2008 1 .

We, therefore, decided in 2010 to revert to the earlier methodology of recycling COEs using actual vehicle de-registrations, but to be more responsive by shortening the lag time to six months, instead of one year under the previous system. With this change, we were able to achieve vehicle population growth much closer to the allowable growth rate. In 2011, the vehicle population grew within the 1.5% allowed.

Page: 512

However, no matter which method of determining the replacement COE supply we use, the underlying issues are that our vehicle population age profile is not uniform, and vehicle owners de-register their vehicles based on multiple considerations. Therefore, de-registration patterns will be uneven, resulting in fluctuations in the COE quota supply.

On the issue of COE price fluctuation, apart from the supply of COEs, there are other factors at play. These include how well our economy is doing, the interest rate environment and even the introduction of new models by motor dealers. Keeping the COE quota supply constant will not prevent COE prices from moving to levels to match demand and supply.

The core constraint of land-scarcity and the need for reasonably flowing traffic even at peak hours, require us to maintain an adequately tight control over the vehicle population growth rate. However, we will continue to review the VQS to refine its implementation.

1 The vehicle growth rate was reduced to 1.5% in 2009.

Page: 512

Assessment of Hazards at Incident Sites to Prevent SCDF Officers from Sustaining Injuries

36 Ms Sylvia Lim asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Home Affairs (a) what procedures are in place to ensure that Singapore Civil Defence Force (SCDF) officers attending to incidents are apprised of the hazards they face at the site before they are deployed thereto; and (b) in the case of the SCDF officers attending to the collapsed roof at the Downtown Line on 18 July 2012, whether the chemical burns sustained were foreseen and could have been prevented.

Mr Teo Chee Hean : The safety of officers during operations is a primary concern of the SCDF, and this is ingrained in every officer from the moment they begin basic training with the force.

Upon arriving at an incident site, SCDF officers will conduct an Appreciation of Situation to assess the potential hazards and risks. This includes gathering as much information as possible about the site and the incident from the fire safety manager and security personnel on-site. Where the incident involves hazardous materials, steps will be taken to minimise the risks of injury to the officers, including the deployment of detectors and the wearing of suitable protective gear. Commanders are trained to adapt the mitigating measures deployed according to the dynamics of the operation to safeguard their own safety and the safety of their officers.

In the Downtown Line recovery operation on 18 July, a key concern was the structural integrity and stability of the site. SCDF had to deploy officers into the heart of the collapsed area to search for the two missing workers. The Commander was in close contact with engineers from the Land Transport Authority and the construction company responsible for the site. Apart from deploying a paramedic team on-site, everyone working in the risk area wore gloves, helmets, goggles and long-sleeved coveralls. The operation proceeded only after the Commander had assessed that the risks were manageable. While the rescue effort was ongoing, SCDF deployed a safety officer to monitor any unusual movement of the collapsed structures.

Page: 513

The search zone was cluttered with metal scaffolding and debris, and filled with viscous concrete mixture reaching up to waist level. To locate the missing workers, our officers had to manoeuvre their way through the mixture since there was no way to know what was submerged underneath. It was a race against time as the concrete mixture was drying. After consulting the on-site engineers, SCDF used water jets to prolong the setting process. It took time to retrieve the bodies as they were pinned down by collapsed scaffolding, metal frames, reinforced bars and wooden planks that had to be removed piece by piece. The search and extrication effort was laborious, complex and challenging.

Despite the safety measures employed, nine rescuers sustained chemical burns on their limbs due to chemical additives in the concrete mixture. They were later conveyed to the hospital where they received outpatient treatment. All nine officers have since reported back to work, most as early as the following shift duty after the incident.

As in most SCDF operations, the risks to personal safety were real and significant. This was carefully considered before the operation commenced, and all possible steps to minimise them were taken.

Page: 513

Adequacy of MediShield Coverage Given Rising Healthcare Costs

37 Ms Foo Mee Har asked the Minister for Health (a) how comprehensively the enhanced MediShield insurance scheme covers the healthcare needs of Singaporeans and whether it is adequate in helping them cope with rising healthcare costs as well as longer life expectancy; (b) how Singapore's enhanced MediShield scheme compares with universal health insurance schemes offered in other countries such as Australia; and (c) what it will take to offer comprehensive universal healthcare coverage for Singaporeans in order to protect them from the burden of healthcare costs.

Mr Gan Kim Yong : To ensure that healthcare is affordable to their citizens, countries adopt different approaches to healthcare financing. Some do so primarily through subsidies while others do so through universal health insurance schemes, where members pay premiums which are risk-pooled to cover healthcare expenses. Each approach has its own pros and cons.

In Singapore, we have adopted a hybrid, which combines Government subsidies for healthcare services (up to 80% in hospitals and 75% in polyclinics), with the 3M system to help Singaporeans pay for their share of the bills after subsidy.

The first M Medisave is a savings scheme for medical expenses. The Government provides Medisave top-ups for Singaporeans from time to time, thus helping Singaporeans to grow their Medisave savings. In Budget 2012, the Government announced the GST Voucher scheme to provide annual Medisave top-ups for all lower-income elderly Singaporeans.

The second M MediShield is an insurance scheme that helps pay for larger bills. This stretches Medisave monies through risk-pooling. More than 90% of Singaporeans are covered under MediShield.

Page: 514

The third M Medifund acts as a final safety net, to help all who need financial assistance for their healthcare expenses. We have systematically topped up the Medifund endowment sum since 2007, increasing the annual assistance available from about $60 million to close to $100 million.

Under this unique approach, all Singaporeans have good access to quality healthcare services so that no one is denied needed medical care because of affordability.

MediShield should not be taken in isolation, but as part of the comprehensive healthcare financing framework. Therefore, it cannot be directly compared with universal health insurance schemes adopted by other countries.

Proposals to enhance MediShield (which are under public consultation) will further improve coverage, to include patients with psychiatric conditions, older Singaporeans and increase payouts on an annual and lifetime basis. We are also studying whether it should cover babies born with congenital conditions.

My Ministry will continue to strengthen the 3M system to improve coverage for Singaporeans and give them greater peace of mind.

Page: 514

MediShield Coverage Beyond Maximum Age

38 Mr David Ong asked the Minister for Health (a) what is the current number of MediShield policyholders who have not fully expended their lifetime limit of $200,000 in claims upon reaching the maximum coverage age; and (b) whether the Ministry will consider extending MediShield coverage beyond the maximum coverage age for policyholders who have not fully expended their lifetime limit by then.

Mr Gan Kim Yong : The number of MediShield policyholders who exceeded the current lifetime limit of $200,000 was 11 in 2010 and 43 in 2011. We expect the number to continue to increase as policyholders age and accumulate more claims over time.

Hence, to provide more assurance to MediShield members, we intend to extend the MediShield lifetime limit from $200,000 to $300,000, as well as the policy year limit, from $50,000 to $70,000. We will also raise the MediShield maximum coverage age from 85 to 90 years to benefit older Singaporeans.

Based on the current life expectancy profile of our population, a relatively small proportion of Singaporeans live beyond age 90. As such, risk-pooling through insurance may not be the most effective way to help the very old defray their healthcare costs. Help is currently available through other means, like Medifund Silver, which is dedicated to our elderly, and annual Medisave top-ups under the GST Voucher scheme. The Government has also enhanced subsidies in the primary care and intermediate and long-term care sector to further improve the affordability of such services.

We understand that Singaporeans are concerned about coverage beyond age 90, and will continue to study possible options to address this.

Page: 515

Plans for Sporting Events at Marina Bay

40 Mr Nicholas Fang asked the Minister for the Environment and Water Resources if there are plans for Marina Bay to be opened up for use for activities such as swimming and other water sports to facilitate the hosting of sporting events such as triathlons and open water swimming.

Dr Vivian Balakrishnan : I thank the Member for his question. Since 2004, PUB has opened up nine of Singapore's reservoirs for recreational water activities, such as kayaking, canoeing, dragon-boating and fishing. Marina Reservoir, which encompasses the Marina Bay area, is one such reservoir. This has enabled the public to enjoy access to our water bodies and encouraged stronger community ownership in keeping our reservoirs clean. A prime consideration is public safety and health. Safety measures, such as life buoys, safety barriers and demarcation of water activity zones, have been implemented.

My Ministry and PUB recognise that Marina Reservoir is a choice venue for a wide range of water-based activities, given its iconic location at the heart of our city. Secondary contact water activities, such as kayaking and sailing, are already allowed in the Marina Reservoir, and in fact a number of sporting events have been hosted there since its commissioning in 2010, including the kayaking and rowing competitions of the 2010 Youth Olympic Games; the World Extreme Sailing Series and the F1 H20 powerboat race in 2011.

However, primary contact activities, such as wakeboarding, waterskiing and those cited by Mr Fang, are not yet permitted in the Marina Reservoir. We must bear in mind that the reservoir contains raw untreated water from an urban catchment. Marina Reservoir was only recently commissioned and it will take some years for its ecology and water quality to transit towards a stable state. Consequently, it would be prudent to not open the reservoir for primary contact activities prematurely.

PUB has an on-going programme to improve the quality of the water in the Marina Reservoir. This includes the rehabilitation of old sewers and surveillance of industrial and commercial activities in the catchment to minimise contamination of surface runoff collected in the reservoir. In the meantime, I would urge members of the public to continue to play your part in keeping our drains, waterways and water bodies clear of litter and pollutants. For it is only through our collective effort that we can have pristine reservoirs open to everyone.

Page: 515

Business Failure Rates amongst Singapore SMEs

41 Ms Tan Su Shan asked the Minister for Trade and Industry (a) whether there is a rising trend of business failures in Singapore, particularly in the SME segment; (b) if so, what are the reasons for such a trend; and (c) whether the Ministry has determined a tolerable range of failure rates in relation to other developed countries and Singapore's recent history.

Mr Lim Hng Kiang : The Ministry of Trade and Industry has not observed a rising trend of "business failures". For business entities registered under the Companies Act, the Insolvency & Public Trustee's Office's (IPTO) statistics show that the number of companies in compulsory liquidation was 135 in 2009, 142 in 2010 and 113 in 2011.

Page: 516

On a different benchmark, ACRA data shows that new firm formation has been rising over the years. In 2006, there were 45,714 firms formed. The same number reached 55,801 in 2011. Even taking into account of existing firms that ceased operations, there was still a nett increase of new firms formed per year. In 2011, nett new firm formation stood at 13,784, 39% more than in 2006. These numbers, we believe, broadly reflect the active entrepreneurship scene in Singapore, and that our environment remains conducive for new firm formation.

On the question of international comparison, we do not have very good data on overseas "business failure rates" for meaningful comparison. What we know, for instance, is that in the United States, for 10 new businesses formed, about eight to nine businesses would cease operations in the same year. Our comparable numbers are between seven and eight. I think we are slightly better off.

We do not pre-determine a tolerable range of business "failure rates". We believe however, that in a vibrant economy, a certain degree of renewal is healthy and necessary. New firms will be created to take advantage of emerging opportunities while uncompetitive ones wind up and make way for new entries. In this way, our economic resources will be more efficiently utilised.

Page: 516

Availability of Space in JTC Facilities for SMEs

42 Mr Inderjit Singh asked the Minister for Trade and Industry what is the current availability of JTC space for SMEs to operate their businesses.

Mr Lim Hng Kiang : SMEs seeking industrial space typically favour multiple-user factories and single-user standard factories as they are smaller, require less overheads and are easier for SMEs to set up quickly.

For the multiple-user factory segment, JTC currently owns 323,000 square metres of space, which represents 3.7% of the total market segment.

Within JTC's 3.7% holding, at an occupancy rate of 90.9% as at 30 June 2012, there are about 29,000 square metres of space available. For the single-user standard factory segment, JTC has a ready-stock of vacant standard factory units amounting to 65,000 square metres of space. Together, the current available JTC-managed space for SMEs to operate their business amounts to 94,000 square metres.

JTC will continue to ensure a steady supply of industrial space for SMEs in three ways.

First, to ensure ample supply of ready-built space in the market, JTC is increasing the supply of industrial land via the Industrial Government Land Sales (iGLS). For 2012 and 2013, an estimated 500,000 square metres (5.7% of the base stock of 8.8 million square metres) of multiple-user factory space will be made available to industrialists each year. This is about three times the average annual supply of land released in the past five years.

Second, JTC is also building a pipeline of developments that SMEs can tap on. Let me elaborate on three that will be launched in the next two years.

Page: 517

Come September 2012, JTC will launch the Small Footprint Standard Factories at Tanjong Kling, which will add another 14,800 square metres to its portfolio of standard factory space. These factories are an improved version of JTC's current standard factories. SME tenants will benefit from greater space flexibility as there will be additional structural provisions to allow the easy installation of different material handling systems within the factory.

In 2013, JTC will launch the Surface Engineering Hub and MedTech1 @ MedTech Hub. This will provide another 64,200 square metres of industrial space into the market. These cluster developments will increase the operational and cost competitiveness of SMEs through co-location and shared facilities.

Third, JTC has made provisions for SMEs seeking affordable industrial land to build their customised facilities. SMEs can participate in JTC's land launches via the Open Land Application Scheme (OLAS) or the newly introduced Price-Quality (PQ) Tenders, which releases land with shorter tenures to lower the investment commitments required.

Page: 517

Extension of Home Loan Term to 50 Years

(Implications of longer home loan terms on retirement and financial planning)

45 Mr Lim Biow Chuan asked the Prime Minister in view of the extension of the term of home mortgage loans from banks for up to 50 years, whether there are implications on the property market when making home loans too affordable and what are these implications, if any.

46 Miss Penny Low asked the Prime Minister in view of the ageing demographics and the extension of the term of home mortgage loans from banks for up to 50 years, (a) what are the implications on retirement planning in Singapore; (b) what steps are in place to ensure prudent financial planning; and (c) whether there are new concrete steps in place to prevent an overselling of property.

Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam (for the Prime Minister) : The 50-year mortgage product is currently offered by one bank and the take-up rate has been low. But if it becomes more widespread, it could have adverse implications for borrowers, the property market and banks.

For the borrower, a very long mortgage tenure has two implications. First, he will end up paying more interest. Further, the payment period could stretch past the normal retirement age, when the borrower may no longer have a steady income stream. In other words, the longer tenure loan will cost more and impose a longer-term burden. But mortgage tenure is just one of the factors that both borrowers and banks must assess. MAS will carefully monitor mortgage tenure in the context of how banks structure their mortgage products, as well as the banks' underwriting standards. Sound mortgage underwriting standards help to lower the risks to banks, but also the risk of borrowers taking on loans which may cause them financial difficulties later.

Banks must assess potential borrowers' ability to repay their loans, taking into account their income and other loan obligations. Loan tenures must take into account the borrower's current and likely future income and repayment capacity, especially where the term of the loan extends past the normal retirement age.

Page: 518

Responsibility also lies with the borrower, who must exercise prudence when taking on housing loans. A mortgage loan is a large and long-term commitment. In deciding how much to pay each month for the mortgage, home buyers need to take into account not only their other expenses, but also their post-retirement financial needs. The national financial education programme, MoneySENSE, aims to educate consumers on what they should consider when buying a home or taking a loan, and how they should plan for retirement.

A longer mortgage tenure also has implications for the property market. It could give buyers the impression of improved affordability of housing, given the smaller monthly repayments, although reality is that of a larger long-term debt service burden. Buyers may therefore believe that they are able to afford a larger or more expensive property. If this becomes widespread, it will increase the demand for properties.

The measures taken by the Government and MAS in recent years have helped to reduce the risk of a sharp escalation in property prices. The lowering of caps on loan-to-value (LTV) ratios for housing loans since 2010 has helped to moderate the demand for properties. The average LTV ratio for outstanding housing loans stands at a healthy 44%. The proportion of housing loans where borrowers have difficulty repaying or have defaulted is low, at 0.3%.

The Government will continue to closely monitor the property market and take the steps necessary to promote a stable and sustainable market.

Page: 518

Selection of Books in the Approved Textbook List for Primary Schools

(Adequacy of selected Primary school textbooks in covering content examined in PSLE)

48 Mr Gerald Giam Yean Song asked the Minister for Education (a) how are textbooks used by Primary schools selected by the Ministry for inclusion in the Approved Textbook List (ATL); (b) whether Primary schools are allowed to select textbooks outside of the ATL as their primary text for a subject; and (c) how does the Ministry ensure that all textbooks used by Primary schools are of a uniform and sufficiently high standard to meet the demands of examinations, especially the Primary School Leaving Examination (PSLE).

49 Mr Gerald Giam Yean Song asked the Minister for Education whether the textbooks used by Primary schools are comprehensive enough to cover all the curriculum content examined during the Primary School Leaving Examination (PSLE) without the need for supplementary content and/or materials provided by teachers or tuition centres.

Mr Heng Swee Keat : All textbooks have to be reviewed by a panel of professionals, including MOE curriculum specialists, school teachers and university academics before they are included in the MOE Approved Textbook List (ATL). The review ensures that the content and skills levels in the textbooks are aligned to the subject syllabuses and examinations. In addition, the review ensures that the content in the textbook is current, accurate and appropriate to local and international contexts.

Page: 519

Most schools would use textbooks from the Approved Textbook List. Schools which decide to use textbooks outside of the Approved Textbook List have to review the materials to ensure that the content and skills levels are aligned with those in the syllabus, and are appropriate.

For the PSLE, besides knowledge of content, the test items require students to demonstrate understanding and application of concepts. Questions based on concepts may not always use the same examples in the textbooks. In a Science test item, for instance, the concept of speed may be illustrated by a moving car or a running man.

Textbooks serve as a base, and teachers also use supplementary materials to augment and enrich learning, and for additional practice so as to enhance student understanding of concepts. For example, for students who require more help to learn grammar items in the English Language, schools could produce learning materials to meet this need. Or Science teachers could use videos to demonstrate visually the concept of boiling point. Teachers would use supplementary materials judiciously to meet the specific needs of the students.

MOE assists by developing teaching resources to support the teachers. Together, the textbooks and the instructional materials provided by the teachers will be sufficient to cover the curriculum content required for the PSLE examinations.

More Help for Households on Government Assistance Schemes and Those Living in Rental Flats

50 Mr Ang Wei Neng asked the Acting Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports in light of data which shows that the lowest 20% of income earners are the worse hit by inflation in the first half of 2012, whether the Ministry will consider extending more help to households staying in rental flats and to households that receive financial assistance from the Government.

Mr Chan Chun Sing : We share Mr Ang Wei Neng's concern on the cost pressures faced by low-income households. We have been monitoring the trend and its impact, and have actively extended appropriate additional assistance where necessary.

Our assistance to low-income households comes in different forms, both broad-based and targeted. Broad-based help includes the GST Voucher introduced in Budget 2012. This is a permanent scheme to help lower- and middle-income households with their expenses, in particular, what they pay in GST. It has three components Cash, Medisave and U-Save. A working low-income household 2 staying in a HDB 1-room rental unit can receive $760, which covers more than half of the GST they pay each year. Retiree couples in smaller flats will receive a GST Voucher that will fully offset their yearly GST expenses.

We also deliver targeted assistance under schemes such as ComCare. Delivered through the Community Development Councils (CDCs), ComCare schemes broadly cover the lowest 20th percentile of households. In April this year, we increased the income cap to allow more low-income families to qualify for assistance. Families that need temporary help can apply for assistance if they earn up to $1,700 per month. To ensure help for larger families, we also introduced a per capita income criterion.

We will continue to monitor the situation closely and make adjustments to MCYS assistance measures where necessary. The assistance the Government provides to low-income households also extend beyond MCYS and ComCare to other areas, such as education, healthcare and housing. The Government will continue to ensure that the low-income receive the comprehensive assistance they need.
