Government Procurement Processes

(Measures to ensure fair and open competition among bidders)

3 Ms Tan Su Shan asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance whether past and current Government procurement processes ensure that the bidding is indeed open to the market and whether the processes are designed to ensure fair competition amongst bidders and good value-for-money for our fellow Singaporeans.

Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam : Singapore's Government procurement system is based on the principles of open and fair competition for public tenders, getting value for money, and an unequivocal stance against corruption or any other abuse of the trust placed in public officers.

Page: 552

All Government agencies are required to post their invitations to tender and quote on the Government Electronic Business portal, or GeBIZ. It is an accessible platform, and levels the playing field for smaller suppliers especially. To ensure transparency, Government agencies are also required to publish on GeBIZ the schedule of bids and notices of award after the tender or quotation has closed.

Anyone can search for business opportunities easily on GeBIZ. It is also easy for suppliers to register as GeBIZ Trading Partners. They get a free user account, which enables them to download quotation and tender documents, and submit their bids electronically.

The GeBIZ system is not passive. GeBIZ Trading Partners can sign up to receive alerts on relevant business opportunities. Government agencies may also alert suppliers to opportunities posted openly on GeBIZ through the GeBIZ alert system, or through phone calls or publicity on their own websites. This is to ensure that the contract receives sufficient attention from potential bidders, without compromising fairness and transparency.

MOF will encourage agencies to proactively alert potential suppliers when procuring unusual or atypical products or services, in case these suppliers are not registered with GeBIZ or are not already receiving alerts.

We will extend the minimum opening period for suppliers to submit bids for quotations (that is, for Government contracts of between $3,000 and $70,000 in value), from the current requirement of four working days to seven working days. This will help ensure that suppliers are given a fair chance to bid for such contracts. Where there are exigencies which require a shorter opening period, the approval of a Director (or equivalent) may be sought.

For larger procurements, which are handled by tenders, the minimum opening period is already set at 14 calendar days (or 25 calendar days if the tender is covered under Singapore's international trade agreements). In practice, many tenders are open for longer than the minimum period.

Suppliers' proposals will only be considered if they meet the requirements stipulated in the invitation to tender or quote. They are then evaluated on the basis of overall benefits and costs. Value for Money does not necessarily mean going for the lowest bid. Upholding Value for Money requires officers to evaluate bids holistically, taking into account the quality and reliability of the product over its life cycle. Public officers can be assured that they will not be penalised for doing so.

Overall, our system of public sector procurement is in good working order. We have sound rules which are in line with international standards, and a dedicated corps of public sector officers, the majority of whom live up to the conduct we expect of them. But in a system with 80,000 procurements each year, some lapses will occur. We, therefore, place importance on independent audits, open channels for irregularities to be reported, and robust enforcement action when any wrong-doing is established.

Page: 553

It is, therefore, a whole system that upholds procurement integrity and deters wrong-doing. This is elaborated on in the oral reply by Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance in response to related questions by Members at this sitting.

Page: 553

Replacement of Overhead Power Cables with Underground Cables

4 Mr Inderjit Singh asked the Minister for Trade and Industry whether the Ministry will consider replacing all remaining overhead power cables in Singapore with underground cables.

Mr Lim Hng Kiang : The installation of new overhead power cables to distribute electricity was discontinued in the late 1970s. However, some older estates are still served by overhead power cables. Currently, around 9,000 electricity users, representing less than 1% of all users, are supplied via overhead power cables.

The overhead power cables continue to work well, and the grid operator, SP PowerGrid (SPPG), has no plans to proactively replace them. Users who wish to convert their overhead power cables to underground supply can request SPPG to do so. The costs of conversion are borne by the users who request the switch to underground supply, as it would not be equitable for SPPG to bear these costs and subsequently recover them from all electricity users. Converting to underground supply could also create some inconvenience for the users, as construction work may need to be carried out within their premises. Hence, it is only when these older estates or units are re-developed that the owners or users would be required to convert to underground supply.

Page: 553

Impact of Data Privacy Laws on Consumer Data and Data Residency

5 Mr Zaqy Mohamad asked the Minister for Information, Communications and the Arts whether the impact on local Internet Service Providers and the Government's promotion of cloud services has been assessed in his Ministry's development of data privacy laws on consumer data and data residency and tighter data regulations for sectors such as banking.

Assoc Prof Dr Yaacob Ibrahim : The development of a data protection law for Singapore was motivated by two key considerations enhanced protection of consumers' personal data against misuse, and the potential economic benefits for Singapore.

A data protection law will strengthen Singapore's position as a trusted and secure hub for businesses. It will also enhance Singapore's attractiveness as a location for global data management activities, such as cloud computing and business analytics.

The proposed data protection law, which will be called the Personal Data Protection Act (PDPA), will recognise that several sectors are presently governed by respective sectoral laws and regulations that may accord higher standards for the protection of personal data. The PDPA will, thus, be a baseline law that will operate concurrently with existing sectoral laws and regulations.

Page: 554

The Government has also been mindful of the need to keep compliance costs of the PDPA manageable for businesses. A series of consultations were conducted between September 2011 to April 2012 to seek public and industry feedback. These have been taken into consideration and will be incorporated in the proposed law, where possible. For instance, one feedback received highlighted the need to cater to organisations that have little or no control over the processing of personal data. This applies to organisations that may merely play an intermediary role, such as the Internet Service Providers (ISPs) in relation to the Internet traffic they carry on behalf of their users. Taking such organisations into consideration, the proposed PDPA will impose fewer obligations on "data intermediaries", which are organisations that merely process personal data on behalf of another party.

Overall, the proposed PDPA aims to strike a balance between the protection of consumers' interests and the need to keep compliance costs manageable for businesses. The proposed data protection is, therefore, expected to provide greater protection for consumers, while reaping economic benefits for Singapore by creating a conducive environment for global data management and processing industries, such as cloud computing, to thrive in Singapore.

Page: 554

Update on Redevelopment of the Malay Heritage Centre

6 Assoc Prof Fatimah Lateef asked the Minister for Information, Communications and the Arts if he can provide an update on the progress of the redevelopment of the Malay Heritage Centre.

Assoc Prof Dr Yaacob Ibrahim : The new Malay Heritage Centre (MHC) will officially re-open to the public in September 2012, after having completed the majority of MHC's redevelopment works, as scheduled in June 2012. The new MHC will feature revamped permanent galleries, new temporary exhibition spaces, an auditorium, a visitor centre and a learning garden.

The new MHC will highlight the history of Kampong Gelam as a port town and its significance to the Malay community, and will showcase the different aspects of Malay culture and heritage that originated from the Indo-Malay Archipelago. The new MHC hopes to highlight the connection between the past heritage of Malays in Singapore and the present, while acknowledging the progress of the Malay community and its contributions. This will be done through a series of public lectures and workshops to increase public awareness.

Throughout its redevelopment period, MHC has been actively engaging key stakeholders through focus group sessions to seek feedback on both the redevelopment works and on the centre's future programmes. These stakeholders, which include community elders, Malay art and heritage practitioners, Kampong Gelam stakeholders, Malay organisations, students and educators, have indicated support for MHC's redevelopment works and have provided useful feedback.

For instance, they have requested for more joint activities with the Malay community, as well as more outdoor programmes to attract Singaporeans and tourists to the precinct. In response to stakeholders' feedback, MHC has organised joint activities, such as the recent Heritage Hunt for children involving the Kampong Gelam stakeholders, and developed outdoor programmes, such as the popular "Neighbourhood Sketches" featuring Malay arts and cultural performances along the streets of Kampong Gelam

Singapore Arts Festival

(Reason for decision to halt for a year)

7 Miss Penny Low asked the Minister for Information, Communications and the Arts (a) what is his assessment of the recently concluded Singapore Arts Festival in terms of reaching out and connecting with citizens; and (b) if it was successful, what is the reason for the decision to halt the Festival for a year instead of carrying on to build the momentum, even if done on a smaller scale.

Assoc Prof Dr Yaacob Ibrahim : I would like to thank the hon Member of Parliament, Miss Penny Low, for her question.

The Singapore Arts Festival 2012 was held from 18 May to 2 June this year, with the theme of "Our Lost Poems" which sought to explore myths, legends and untold stories. In line with the call for arts and culture to be an integral part of the lives of Singaporeans, this year's programming strategy focused on being more community-centric and on enhancing the accessibility of the Festival, both in terms of content and availability of free programmes.

The Festival this year was a more compact one, featuring more artists over a shorter period. A total of 772 local and foreign artists were featured in over 380 performances over 16 days. More than two-thirds of these performances were free, as part of the Festival's commitment to make the arts more accessible to Singaporeans. As a result, total non-ticketed attendance was at a three-year high of over 140,000, almost three times that of 2010 and almost seven times that of last year.

These programmes brought together a wide demographic of Singapore's population from senior citizens to youths and students and also gave ordinary individuals from the local communities a platform to perform and share their personal stories with the public for the first time. I would like to highlight, in particular, the Bridge Caf Project, where Japanese choreographer Kim Itoh worked with a team of local arts practitioners to bring together 17 youths and 13 middle-aged men, or "uncles" as they are affectionately known, to become performer-waiters in a Caf set up at the Festival Village. These performer-waiters would break out into song and dance while serving Caf patrons, eliciting warm applause and many smiles. The Bridge Caf project not only gave our "uncles" an opportunity to recapture their youth and ignite their interest in the arts, but also brought our youths and seniors together in a meaningful way.

Besides involving the community as audience members and performers, the Festival also offered opportunities for our people to be involved as volunteers. This year, a record of 496 Festival Ambassadors participated in the Festival, contributing in areas, such as artist liaison and venue hosting.

The highlight of the Festival this year was the Festival Village, which registered 120,000 visitors, a six-fold increase from 2011. This success can be attributed to the all-free calendar for the Festival Village this year, with targeted programming time belts and interactive programmes that helped the Festival Village better attract and connect with more audiences.

Page: 556

Although this year's Festival achieved a significant level of engagement with our patrons, it is necessary for us to continually review its formula and prepare for the future, particularly as our arts landscape has changed significantly since the Festival started 35 years ago.

As I had shared in my response to the hon Member Ms Irene Ng last week, the decision to put the Arts Festival on hold for 2013 was a difficult one for MICA to make. However, in view of the long-term benefits, we decided that a temporary break was justified and worthwhile. The one-year hiatus of the Festival would give the review team the time and space to take a step back and undertake an objective and holistic review of the Festival, in close partnership with the local arts community and key stakeholders.

To conclude, I would like to assure Members that MICA recognises the significance of the Singapore Arts Festival to our people. We are confident that the ongoing Review will help us build a stronger Festival for the future, and we encourage the arts community and general public to give their views and work with the Government towards this goal.

Page: 556

Public Spaces for Visual Artists

8 Mr Yee Jenn Jong asked the Minister for Information, Communications and the Arts whether the Ministry will consider setting aside selected public spaces for visual artists to create street art and what are some of the considerations in terms of regulations and possible locations if such spaces are to be created.

Assoc Prof Dr Yaacob Ibrahim : The Government embraces street art as one of many art forms in the variety of genres it supports from traditional to contemporary, high art to popular entertainment and craft, and in performing, visual, literary and multi-disciplinary forms.

MICA recognises the role of street art as a form of creative expression by the community, particularly our youths. Street art, which is art developed in public spaces, can inject new and diverse elements into urban life. With its high visibility and grounds-up approach, street art also allows the community accessibility and easy entry into the arts and culture. When properly executed with the approval of the property owner, street art can thus play a role in our next phase of cultural development by enlivening our physical landscape and helping to expand the space for creative expression by Singaporeans.

Street artists currently enjoy a wide range of venues in which they can showcase their talent, through events and activities held at art venues, youth parks and community spaces, including libraries. Besides showcase platforms, street art also receives support from the Government through funding support and in the form of youth-targeted programmes.

In terms of venues and platforms where street artists can showcase their talent, both the National Arts Council (NAC) and National Heritage Board (NHB) work closely with venue partners who are keen to display and incorporate expressions of street art into their buildings. For example, the Substation, one of NAC's arts housing tenants, has on occasion invited various street art makers to display their works on the wall of its building.

Page: 557

NHB has also partnered street artists as well as residents for some of its community outreach activities, such as the community co-creation project at the upcoming Taman Jurong Community Museum. 9 In addition, NHB will also organise street art mural workshops, where artists are invited to share techniques of street art and to work jointly with the community on street art murals. Mass outreach programmes will also be carried out to provide residents with more opportunities to be exposed to and be engaged in arts and heritage-related activities.

With the growing interest in street art, particularly among our youths, the NAC has also incorporated the art form into its youth arts programmes. For example, as part of NAC's NOISE programme for youths 10 , NAC and the National Library Board (NLB) jointly organised a series of street art workshops in December 2011, which culminated in a showcase of participants' works at Jurong Regional Library and Yishun Public Library earlier this year. Besides programmes by NAC and NLB, the Youth Park and *Scape at Orchard Road also provide spaces and platforms for graffiti art and other such forms of urban art to be displayed.

The NAC views visual expressions in street art as a form of visual arts, and is open to providing grant support, as it does for all forms of the visual arts be it street art, painting, photography, sculpture, installation or performance art.

As there already exists a healthy range of venues and platforms to showcase street art in Singapore, MICA views that there is currently no necessity to set aside new designated areas for street art. Instead, given the merit of street art and its potential to further engage the community, MICA and our agencies will continue to provide support to encourage street art to be practised and showcased responsibly in a wide range of public venues. Looking forward, MICA will continue to review its efforts to create a vibrant and sustainable cultural eco-system which allows for the cultivation of diversity and accessibility in our arts and cultural landscape.

9 The National Heritage Board (NHB), in partnership with the People's Association (PA) and Taman Jurong Community Club (TJCC), is developing a pilot Community Museum at Taman Jurong, with the aim of bringing our communities together through art, culture and heritage. The Community Museum will serve as an exhibition space for the display of items from the national collection and also as a platform to showcase community creations. Community involvement will be a key focus of the project, through various public programmes and community co-creation/curation opportunities.. NHB commissioned local artist Speak Cryptic to work with Taman Jurong residents on a series of wall murals, for which residents were involved in both the conceptualisation as well as the execution of the murals.
10 An initiative of the National Arts Council, NOISE Singapore is dedicated to showcasing the creative talent of young people aged 35 and below. Through numerous platforms to express, develop and showcase their creativity, NOISE Singapore hopes to encourage young people in Singapore to actively participate and nurture their relationship with the arts, as well as get them spotted for their budding abilities.

Public Service Broadcast (PSB) Funding and Viewership

9 Ms Janice Koh asked the Minister for Information, Communications and the Arts in 2010 and 2011 respectively (a) how much Public Service Broadcast (PSB) funding was allocated to independent production houses; (b) how many television shows were supported and what was the total number of content hours produced by independent production houses with PSB funds; and (c) what was the breakdown of those content hours, by genre, for drama; info-entertainment programmes; information programmes; children's programmes; arts, culture and heritage programmes; and sports programmes.

Page: 558

10 Ms Janice Koh asked the Minister for Information, Communications and the Arts of the 4.3 million television viewers who watched locally-produced Public Service Broadcast (PSB) programmes last year, what is the breakdown of the viewership by programme genre, in terms of drama; info-entertainment programmes; information programmes; children's programmes; arts, culture and heritage programmes; and sports programmes, excluding the news.

Assoc Prof Dr Yaacob Ibrahim : In the Financial Years (FY) 2010 and 2011, Public Service Broadcast (PSB) funding catered for the provision of over 2,000 hours of local productions 11 each year, broadcast across MediaCorp's seven free-to-air (FTA) TV channels. This amounted to over 200 programme titles each year.

In each of the two years, about 40% of local PSB programme hours and funding for such programmes were allocated for outsourcing by MediaCorp to independent production companies. The requirement for MediaCorp to outsource PSB hours is an integral part of the PSB framework, as it: (i) ensures the selection of concepts for quality PSB productions from a larger pool of creative ideas from the industry; and (ii) contributes to the development of the local production sector.

In terms of the genre composition of PSB-funded local programme hours, about 60% comprise news 12 and information programmes, which includes current affairs, documentaries and info-education programmes. This reflects the emphasis placed on PSB in serving the Singapore public's information and educational needs via a variety of PSB programmes. The remaining 40% of local PSB programme hours cover a range of genres to serve the diverse viewing needs of the Singapore public. These include children's, arts and cultural, and sports programming, dramas and programmes for the elderly. Other than news and current affairs programmes, which are generally managed by MediaCorp's in-house production teams, independent production companies undertake productions for a variety of programme genres.

The Media Development Authority's (MDA) PSB performance management framework tracks PSB viewership 13 by the seven FTA TV channels, each serving a different target audience demographic. In FY2011, among the English-language channels, the funded PSB programmes garnered the following viewership among their respective target demographics: (i) about 60% (about 2.9 million) of viewers aged four and above for Channel 5; (ii) about 60% of PMEBs 14 (about 110,000) for Channel NewsAsia Singapore; (iii) about 70% (about 340,000) of viewers aged four to 12 for Okto's children's programme belt; and about 15% (about 600,000) of viewers aged 15 and above for Okto's arts and culture programme belt.

On Vasantham and Suria, local PSB programmes were watched by about 80% (about 370,000) of Indian viewers aged four and above and about 90% (about 560,000) of Malay viewers aged four and above, respectively. As for Channel 8 and Channel U, local PSB programmes were viewed by about 70% (about 3.3 million) of viewers aged four and above, and about 55% (about 2.3 million) of viewers aged 15 and above respectively.

Page: 559

In assessing PSB viewership performance by channel, it is important to consider factors that influence each channel's ability to reach its target audience. These include the nature of the FTA TV channel whether it is a mass or niche channel and the degree of audience fragmentation among the channel's target demographic. For instance, with the wide availability of foreign English-language programmes from competing sources, audience fragmentation among the English-speaking audience tends to be higher.

It should also be noted that while viewership is a basic form of performance measurement for PSB programmes, it is not the sole indicator that MDA uses to assess the effectiveness of these programmes. MDA's PSB performance management framework takes a holistic view of PSB effectiveness by including other indicators, such as the level of public satisfaction with PSB programmes and qualitative feedback from community and industry stakeholders. The information on performance gathered is subsequently used during regular engagements between MDA and MediaCorp to discuss improvements that could be made to PSB programming and delivery.

While the viewership information indicates a reasonable level of performance, we must continue to engage and grow viewership and audience appreciation for PSB programmes by enhancing the quality of our PSB programmes to meet the public's expectations. We will also need to exploit the full potential of reaching audiences through multi-screen programme offerings and via Internet platforms. These are issues which MDA will continue to work on, together with our local industry partners, to raise the bar for PSB programmes, as guided by the recently accepted PSB Review Panel's recommendations.

11 PSB funding caters for over 4,000 hours of programmes each year, of which over 2,000 are local productions. The remaining hours are acquired programmes, such as educational and arts/culture programmes, which help to supplement the overall PSB content offering.
12 News programmes receive some PSB funding support, but by and large, MediaCorp is obligated to provide news at its own cost.
13 Source of PSB viewership information is Kantar Media's TV Audience Measurement System.
14 PMEB refers to professionals, managers, executives and businessmen with monthly incomes of S$5,000 and above.

Supply of Sheep for Korban for Hari Raya Haji

11 Mr Zaqy Mohamad asked the Minister for Information, Communications and the Arts and Minister-in-charge of Muslim Affairs (a) whether MUIS plans to consider alternative sources of sheep for the annual korban ritual for Hari Raya Haji to ensure that participation remains affordable to ordinary Muslim citizens; (b) whether MUIS will consider tiering the procurement of sheep by allowing part of the supply to revert to sea-borne transport for citizens seeking cheaper alternatives; (c) whether the recent requirement by Australia has resulted in any increase in korban costs; and (d) whether increases in our korban prices have resulted in more Singaporeans performing their korban ritual overseas.

Assoc Prof Dr Yaacob Ibrahim : Korban is a key religious ritual observed by the Muslim community every year. We currently import the animals for this purpose from Australia.

Prior to 2009, all livestock for korban were imported via sea-freight. However, following the late delivery of livestock for korban in 2005, the Singapore Mosques Korban Committee decided to use air freight as mode of delivery for korban livestock. Although the cost of air freight is more expensive, it provides greater certainty that the livestock will arrive in Singapore in time for korban as well as mitigates unforeseen risks due to inclement weather conditions that are inherent in sea-freight delivery.

Page: 560

With effect from 1 September 2012, Australian exporters seeking a permit to export livestock to Singapore must comply with the new regulatory framework known as the Exporter Supply Chain Assurance System. It is likely that the costs of korban will increase this year due to the need to comply with the stringent requirements for korban facilities and equipment as well as the cost of engaging auditors to conduct performance audit during korban.

The Agri-Food and Veterinary Authority of Singapore (AVA) and MUIS are exploring alternative sources for livestock imports for future korbans. However, we need to consider various factors, such as whether the alternative sources meet our animal health and veterinary public health requirements and transport options.

Korban is an act of charity for those with the means to do so. It can be performed in Singapore or overseas. Many Singaporeans have been performing korban overseas in the past and many will continue to do so in the future. However, we will continue to work with the relevant authorities to ensure our mosques can continue to provide korban services for those who wish to perform korban locally.

Disbursements of Zakat Collection Under Asnaf

12 Mr Muhamad Faisal Bin Abdul Manap asked the Minister for Information, Communications and the Arts and Minister-in-charge of Muslim Affairs from 2006 to 2010 (a) in the administration of zakat under the "Fisabilillah" category (Asnaf), what is the amount allocated by MUIS to the Madrasah Development and Assistance sub-category; and (b) what are the annual amounts disbursed to each of the six full-time madrasahs and how are these amounts decided.

In the last five years, MUIS has allocated an average sum of $3.3 million per year from zakat for madrasah development. The amount provided to each of the six madrasah varies, depending on needs.

In addition, all six madrasahs have also received a total of $5.18 million in the last five years in direct funding from Dana Madrasah 16 , or Madrasah Fund. This funding is primarily used for student and teacher development, which are the key areas to improve the overall quality of our madrasah education.

The funding components in each madrasah are as follows:

(i) $300 grant for every Primary 5 and 6 student for PSLE remedial and enrichment programmes, given that madrasah students are also required to sit for the PSLE under the Compulsory Education Act;

Page: 561

(ii) $13,500 grant for each m adrasah for student programmes and miscellaneous expenses for running the school library and organising events, such as sports day;

To date, 73 teachers have obtained their Diploma in Education qualification and another 76 teachers have graduated from the Specialist Diploma Programme at the National Institute of Education (NIE). MUIS also ensures financial support to needy students in the six full-time madrasahs. Since 2010, MUIS has tapped on its Progress Fund to render these students assistance packages, a large portion of which covers school fees. In 2011, 269 students benefited from the Madrasah Financial Assistance Scheme, which is one of the programmes under MUIS' Progress Fund.

15 Fisabilillah means "Strive in the cause of Allah for the betterment of the community". This includes religious programmes, mosque leadership and administration, madrasah development and assistance, youth development and engagement, dakwah, Islamic education, asatizah development and community development.
16 Dana Madrasah is a fund created in 1994 to address all six full-time madrasahs' immediate financial needs. The three main sources of contributions to Dana Madrasah are individual donations, mosques and the MUIS Zakat Fund.

Sale of Flats by Permanent Residents upon Reaching Subletting Cap

13 Mr Ang Hin Kee asked the Minister for National Development in view of the recently revised subletting rules for Permanent Residents (PRs), whether the Ministry will consider making it mandatory for PRs who are no longer residing in their flats to sell them once the five-year subletting cap is reached.

Mr Khaw Boon Wan : Singapore Permanent Resident (PR) flat owners are allowed to sublet their flats after meeting the Minimum Occupation Period for the flat, if they have not sublet the flat before. The total period of subletting is capped at five years.

PR flat owners who have reached the five-year cap for subletting will be required to resume occupation of their HDB flats. Those who no longer need the flats for their own occupation will be required to sell their flats.

Effect of 50-Year Home Mortgage Bank Loans on HDB Flats

15 Mr Chen Show Mao asked the Minister for National Development what likely effect will 50-year home mortgage bank loans have on the prices, financing and affordability of HDB flats.

Mr Khaw Boon Wan : Fifty-year housing loans will cost the borrowers more, besides imposing a longer term financial burden on them. While such loans offer lower monthly instalments, the borrowers will end up paying higher interest in total, and servicing the loan past their retirement when they no longer have a steady income.

While some borrowers may be attracted by the lower monthly instalments, we do not expect 50-year housing loans to be popular. Their impact on the public housing market is unlikely to be significant.

HDB does not offer 50-year loans as they are not necessary. We price BTO flats to be affordable, well within one working lifetime. There is no need for working couples to take 50-year mortgages to buy HDB flats. The maximum loan tenure for HDB housing loans is 30 years, with an age ceiling of 65. In practice, the average loan tenure taken up is lower, at 24 years. At this loan tenure, the monthly housing loan instalment constitutes about a quarter of the monthly household income, and can be mostly paid for using CPF contributions, with zero or minimum cash outlay.

Page: 562

Debt Collection Tactics Used by Licensed Moneylenders

16 Er Dr Lee Bee Wah asked the Minister for Law whether there is any restriction on the tactics used by licensed moneylenders to seek the return of debts from borrowers, such as approaching borrowers at their place of employment to collect debts.

Mr K Shanmugam : Licensed moneylenders may take reasonable steps to recover their debts as long as they do not infringe the law. Such steps include contacting the borrower to ask for repayment and taking legal action to enforce the loan contract. Approaching a debtor at his place of employment to collect debts, whilst potentially embarrassing, does not constitute an offence.

However, moneylenders cannot resort to harassment, vandalism, violence or threatening behaviour when recovering debts. Borrowers who encounter such behaviour should report the matter to the Police for investigation. Moneylenders found to have committed such offences may have their licence suspended, not renewed, or revoked by the Registry of Moneylenders.

We have been closely monitoring the moneylending industry, including the debt collection practices of moneylenders. We tightened regulations last November, by requiring moneylenders to seek the Registry of Moneylenders' prior approval for the engagement of any person to assist in all aspects of their business, including the collection of debts.

Page: 563

We are studying measures to further tighten debt collection practices of moneylenders. These include stricter regulation as to whom licensed moneylenders may engage as debt collectors, and regulations relating to debt collection practices by moneylenders.

As part of MinLaw's continuing efforts to enhance the professionalism of the moneylending industry and strengthen its governance, we have been closely consulting with stakeholders, including the Moneylender's Association of Singapore. We have received suggestions, from the industry, to introduce paid-up capital requirements for moneylenders, similar to the requirements for banks and finance companies. We have studied the suggestions and are in the process of working out the details, such as the quantum, with a view to introducing these and other requirements by the end of this year.

Update on Disbursement of Community Silver Trust Funds

This will enable them to build up their capabilities and programmes in intermediate and long-term care. About 12,000 clients currently served by these VWOs stand to benefit from this additional funding.

Page: 563

EV-71 Epidemic Situation in Cambodia and Updates on Hand, Foot and Mouth Disease Situation in Singapore

18 Dr Lam Pin Min asked the Minister for Health (a) if the Ministry is monitoring the EV-71 epidemic situation in Cambodia; (b) if he will provide updates on (i) the current Hand, Foot and Mouth Disease (HFMD) situation in Singapore; and (ii) whether there have been local cases of EV-71 infection in the last three months; and (c) whether there is any surveillance system in place to monitor any importation of the deadly EV-71 strain.

Page: 564

Mr Gan Kim Yong : MOH is closely monitoring the Enterovirus 71 (EV-71) situation in Cambodia, and has been in contact with its Cambodian counterparts and the World Health Organisation. All hospitals in Singapore which provide medical services for children have been alerted to look out for similar cases who had come from, or travelled to, Cambodia. There have been no reports of such cases thus far. To date, there have also been no reports to suggest that the EV-71 strain in Cambodia is a new, more virulent strain.

EV-71 is one of the causes of HDMF, together with other enteroviruses, such as Coxsackieviruses. EV-71 and other enteroviruses circulate continuously in Singapore at varying levels throughout the year.

HFMD is a common childhood disease which is endemic in Singapore and the region. Yearly seasonal outbreaks of HFMD are thus expected. The number of HFMD cases in Singapore this year rose above the epidemic level in the week of 12 February 2012 and reached a peak of 1,686 cases in the week of 13 May 2012. However, the number of cases has since decreased to 871 cases in the week of 22 July 2012. Less than 3% of notified cases of HFMD required hospital admission because of poor food intake, and there were no severe local cases among those hospitalised. In the last three months, 4.1% of the samples collected for MOH's HFMD surveillance programme were positive for EV-71. The current main circulating strains are a mixture of Coxsackieviruses, which are the most common cause of HFMD, and are generally milder than EV-71.

As EV-71 is endemic in Singapore, MOH does not monitor specifically for the importation of EV-71. Nevertheless, MOH has established local surveillance systems to monitor the prevalence of HFMD due to EV-71 and to detect new and emerging infections which could be imported through international trade and travel.

Page: 564

Number of Local and Foreign Medical Technologists Employed in Restructured Hospitals

19 Dr Lam Pin Min asked the Minister for Health (a) what is the current number of medical technologists in the restructured hospitals; (b) what is the ratio of Singaporeans versus foreigners employed; (c) whether there is a shortage of Singaporeans taking up this vocation; and (d) whether the Ministry has plans to encourage Singaporeans to consider this career option.

Mr Gan Kim Yong : There are about 950 Medical/Laboratory Technologists (MLTs) in the restructured hospitals and 92% of them are locals.

The low vacancy rate of 4% and high proportion of locals suggest that there is no immediate shortage of Singaporeans taking up MLT as a career.

Nevertheless, given the important role MLTs play in the restructured hospitals, the Ministry and the public healthcare clusters will continue to work together to attract, develop and retain them.

Doctors in Public Service Freelancing in the Private Sector

20 Mr Seah Kian Peng asked the Minister for Health (a) whether doctors in the public service are allowed to freelance in the private sector; and (b) based on current levels, what percentage of a senior consultant's pay comes from his salary and what percentage comes from seeing private patients.

Page: 565

Mr Gan Kim Yong : As a general policy, public sector doctors are not allowed to freelance in the private sector while remaining an employee of a public healthcare institution. However, public sector doctors may seek special permission from their employer to work part-time in the private sector and such requests are evaluated on a case-by-case basis. Institutions may accede to requests if there are strong reasons, such as the need to retain these doctors to meet the service or education needs of the institutions. Doctors who work part-time in the private sector have to abide by the rules and guidelines set by their respective institutions to protect the interests of the institution. They also continue to see subsidised patients and fulfil other commitments, such as mentoring and teaching of medical students and junior doctors.

In 2011, 82% of the Senior Consultants' salary, on average, was funded by the public healthcare institutions' revenue. This includes their base salary, bonuses and allowances. The remaining 18% of the Senior Consultants' salary, on average, comprises professional fees levied directly on full paying patients in the public healthcare institutions.

Estimated Total Expenditure on Healthcare and Long-Term Care for the Elderly and Projections for Tax Revenues

21 Mr Gerald Giam Yean Song asked the Minister for Health in light of our ageing population (a) what is the Government's estimated total expenditure on healthcare and long-term care for the elderly in 2012; and (b) what are the Government's projections for 2015, 2020, 2025 and 2030 at current birth rates and without immigration for (i) tax revenues at current tax rates; and (ii) total Government expenditure on healthcare and long-term care for the elderly at current subsidy rates and at estimated enhanced subsidy rates respectively.

Mr Gan Kim Yong : MOH's budget in FY2012 is an estimated $4.7 billion, about 20% higher than last year's expenditure. The bulk of this goes to patient subsidies, building infrastructure and developing new services, programmes and manpower capabilities.

As a significant part of healthcare expenditure, like infrastructure and manpower, is shared across the entire user base, it is not possible to provide a precise breakdown on the amount that is spent specifically on the elderly only.

Under the Ministry's Healthcare 2020 plan to ensure accessible, affordable and quality healthcare for all Singaporeans, we had earlier announced initiatives to increase subsidies, expand capacity, increase salaries and invest in the training of healthcare staff, better integrate care, and step up health promotion programmes.

Taking these efforts into consideration, we project that the Government's overall expenditure on health will double over five years, and may reach up to 3.5% of GDP by 2030, from the current 1.6%. These projections are sensitive to factors, such as economic growth, population growth, changing medical technology, healthcare consumption patterns, as well as changes to healthcare services delivery models, among others. We expect the rising proportion of elderly in our population to be one key factor driving this growth, given the greater need for healthcare services among the elderly and the generally longer period of care needed.

Page: 566

Currently, the Government's tax revenues are between 13% and 14% of GDP. We expect it to remain at around this level if we hold tax rates constant.

MediShield Scheme

(Proposed increases in deductibles and premiums)

22 Mr Gerald Giam Yean Song asked the Minister for Health what were the specific underlying actuarial assumptions and actuarial adjustments made to the existing MediShield scheme that resulted in the proposed increases to the MediShield deductibles and premiums.

Mr Gan Kim Yong : MediShield is a not-for-profit insurance scheme focused on protecting Singaporeans against large subsidised bills. MediShield premiums are adjusted from time to time in line with payout experience and the expected changes in benefits, so that it can continue to support policyholders' claims in the future. The premiums are set based on actuarial recommendations by the appointed actuary, Deloitte Actuaries and Consultants Limited, in line with standard actuarial principles and approaches.

The key assumptions and adjustments in the pricing of the MediShield scheme are:

(a) Future expected claims experience by age, based on historical claims experience.

(b) Future expected claims costs adjusted for the proposed schedule of benefits and deductibles.

(c) Premium rebates for older policyholders: Premium rebates are currently provided from ages 71 to 85. A portion of premiums is set aside to support premium rebates for policyholders when they grow older. The rebates will now cover 20 years instead of 15 years with the increase in maximum coverage age, and reflect changes in expected life expectancy.

(d) Projected membership, taking into account lapses, opt-outs, deaths and new members, based on historical trends.

(e) Contingency margin against adverse circumstances.

(f) Current and projected capital position of the MediShield Fund, including projected returns of the fund and administrative costs of the scheme.

Page: 566

Countdown Timer for Pedestrians and Motorists at Major Traffic Light Junctions

23 Er Dr Lee Bee Wah asked the Minister for Transport whether the LTA will consider introducing the countdown timer for pedestrians as well as motorists at all major traffic light junctions.

Page: 567

Mr Lui Tuck Yew : Pedestrian countdown timers are usually installed at signalised pedestrian crossings near schools and at busy junctions. Over the years, they have gained popularity and LTA plans to progressively implement more of them at other locations.

On vehicle countdown timers, LTA had conducted a trial earlier at the junction of North Bridge Road and Rochor Road where motorists were observed to display varying behaviours in reaction to the countdown timer. As the timer approached zero, some motorists applied the brakes to stop while others accelerated to beat the red light. Such differential behaviour increases the risk of rear-end collisions. Recent studies conducted overseas show similar behaviours.

Moreover, vehicle countdown timers are more suitable for traffic light systems that run on a fixed timing because the time will then be more predictable. In Singapore, we use a dynamic system to control and vary traffic light timing according to traffic flow and demand.

Priority for Primary 1 Registration Based on Active Community Leadership

26 Mr Yee Jenn Jong asked the Minister for Education with regard to the priority granted for Primary 1 registration based on active community leadership by the child's parents (a) what constitutes active community leadership; (b) how many children have gained admission to primary schools yearly based on this priority over the past five years; and (c) whether the Ministry plans to review the necessity for this priority.

Mr Heng Swee Keat : Under the current Primary 1 (P1) Registration Framework, current serving committee members of the Residents' Committee (RC), Neighbourhood Committee (NC), Citizen's Consultative Committee (CCC), Community Club Management Committee (CCMC) and the Community Development Council (CDC) are eligible to register their children under Phase 2B as active community leaders. To qualify as active community leaders, the People's Association (PA) requires the community leaders to serve actively in these Committees for at least one year prior to the P1 registration exercise.

While active community leaders can choose to register their child under Phase 2B, there is no guarantee that they will be successful in obtaining a place in their school of choice if the number of applications in Phase 2B exceeds the number of places in a school. In the last five years, an average of 330 children, or less than 1% of the Primary 1 cohort, were admitted annually under the active community leaders scheme.

The Ministry regularly reviews the P1 Registration Framework, taking into consideration the feedback received after every exercise.

Number and Profile of Homeless Persons

28 Mr Laurence Lien asked the Acting Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports (a) what are the numbers of homeless persons, new and cumulative, in the last three years; (b) what is the profile of these persons; (c) what are the root causes of homelessness; and (d) what is being done to tackle these root causes.

Mr Chan Chun Sing : In 2009, 2010 and 2011, MCYS assisted 217, 339 and 264 homeless individuals respectively. Over the same period, we have also provided shelter and support to 72, 128 and 141 families respectively. In total, we assisted 820 such individuals and 341 families over the last three years.

The majority of homeless individuals are men in their 50s who have attained secondary education or lower. The majority of affected families are low-income households (with monthly income of $1, 500 or less) with four or more members and have weak social support.

These individuals and families have housing difficulties due to a variety of reasons. Some had sold their flats to resolve their financial problems and could not afford to purchase or rent another flat in the short-term. Others were unable to stay with their families due to strained family relationships, anti-social behaviour or addiction-related problems.

My Ministry works closely with MND and HDB to address the housing needs of this group. Those who are destitute will be admitted to welfare homes which provide basic accommodation and needs.

In addition, Voluntary Welfare Organisations, Family Service Centres and Community Development Councils provide financial assistance and social intervention to the individuals and families so that they regain their resilience and independence. The support includes equipping them with financial planning and budgeting skills, job training and employment assistance, and relationship management. Efforts are also taken to ensure the children continue to attend school so that their education is not disrupted.

Page: 570

Individuals and families facing housing difficulties can get help early by calling the 24-hour ComCare Hotline at 1800 222 0000. The hotline also caters to those who speak dialects. The public is encouraged to call this hotline if they see anyone who needs assistance.

Number of Citizens Qualified for Public Assistance and ComCare Schemes

Also on 1 April 2012, the household income cap for short- and medium-term ComCare assistance was raised and a per capita income criterion was introduced to provide more help to larger families and those requiring childcare, kindergarten and student care subsidies. From 1 April 2012 to 31 July 2012, over 3,000 households qualified for short and medium term assistance and about 1,900 applications for childcare, kindergarten and student care subsidies were approved. As at 31 July 2012, there were 9,911 households on short- and medium-term assistance, compared to 5,471 households a year ago; 18,997 beneficiaries were receiving childcare, kindergarten and student care subsidies as at 31 July 2012, compared to 18,039 beneficiaries a year ago.

MCYS will continue to monitor and review the adequacy of the ComCare schemes to ensure the needs of the relevant groups are met.

Lease of Farrer Park Swimming Complex to Private Entity

(Award and renewals through public tender)

30 Asst Prof Tan Kheng Boon Eugene asked the Acting Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports (a) whether the initial lease of the Farrer Park swimming complex to a private entity was awarded through a public tender; (b) whether the subsequent renewals of the lease were done through public tenders and, if so, what was the winning bid for each renewal; and (c) whether the Ministry will consider requiring the private operator to provide for more and affordable use of the pool by the public during off-peak hours.

Mr Chan Chun Sing : Farrer Park Swimming Complex was closed to the public on 1 June 2003 due to low utilisation. The Singapore Sports Council (SSC) launched an open Request For Proposal (RFP) in September 2003 to invite the private sector to submit proposals for alternative uses of the closed swimming pool. Two proposals were received. A lease of the facility was awarded to a private entity for a term of five years to 30 July 2009. The winning bidder was assessed to have performed better overall against the evaluation criteria, including the fee which it would pay to SSC for the lease.

Page: 571

After July 2009, the lease was extended on a monthly basis due to the uncertainty of the future plans for the site and when the land would need to be returned for redevelopment. In an audit by the Auditor-General's Office (AGO) which concluded earlier this year, AGO pointed out that in extending the lease, SSC should have carried out a valuation to ascertain the prevailing market rent, regardless of the uncertainty over the long term plans for the site. SSC has now completed a valuation on the market rate, and will be issuing a new tender/RFP in the coming months.

SSC is mindful that sports facilities should remain affordable even if it is operated by a private operator. This was, and will continue to be, part of the criteria of RFP exercises and terms in lease agreements. Flexibility is, however, given to the private operator to determine if it should charge differential fees between peak and off-peak periods based on demand and business considerations.

CPF Dependants' Protection Scheme

(Premium reduction or waiver for low-income Singaporeans)

31 Mr Zainal Sapari asked the Acting Minister for Manpower (a) what is the current number of Singaporeans earning below $1,700 per month who opted out of the CPF Dependants' Protection Scheme; (b) what are the reasons for their opting out of the scheme; and (c) whether the Government can consider a scheme to waive or reduce the premiums for workers earning below $1,700 per month.

32 Mr Patrick Tay Teck Guan asked the Acting Minister for Manpower (a) what is the current number of CPF account holders, with a breakdown in terms of age, gender and salary range, who are (i) on the Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS); and (ii) not on DPS because of their opt-out; and (b) what has been the claims experience in the last five years.

33 Mr Seng Han Thong asked the Acting Minister for Manpower (a) how many CPF members have opted out of the Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS) since its inception and what is the income profile of those who opted out; (b) whether there are plans to review the scheme so that lower-income Singaporeans are adequately protected in view of its opt-out nature; and (c) how will CPF Board incentivise the lower income group to remain in the scheme.

Mr Tan Chuan-Jin : The Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS) is a term insurance scheme that mitigates the impact of a loss of income to a family, in the event that the insured member can no longer work due to permanent incapacity or death. The scheme is automatically extended to CPF members who are Singapore citizens or Permanent Residents, between age 16 and 60, when they make their first CPF contribution.

Being an insurance scheme that protects dependants against loss of income, the priority is, therefore, to ensure that gainfully employed members with dependants are covered by DPS. Currently, about 83% of active CPF members between the age of 16 and 60 are covered under DPS. The share of males and females covered is roughly equal. The rest comprises primarily CPF members who have opted out of the scheme, whose coverage has lapsed, or who are unable to get coverage due to health conditions. Among employees aged between 16 and 60 and earning $1,700 and below, 79% are insured under DPS. This compares to 84% for those earning above $1,700.

Page: 572

In terms of claims experience, there was an average of 2,800 claims per year (about 0.15% of the insured population) between 2007 and 2011. These claims amounted to an average of $143.5 million per year.

Based on data over the past five years, on an annual basis, an average of 1.5% of the DPS members cease their DPS coverage, either because they have opted out of the scheme or lapsed in their premium payments. For those who opted out during this period, more than half had no income, earned $1,700 and below, or were self-employed. A significant proportion, about a third, were young members aged 16 to 20, and likely to have opted out because they did not have dependants to support.

For those whose DPS coverage lapsed due to non-payment of premiums, the vast majority of them had no income or were self-employed, that is, members with no Ordinary Account contributions that can be used to pay for DPS premiums. About half of them were young members aged 16 to 20 who may not have dependants, or older members aged 56 to 60 who may no longer be working and supporting their families. The proportion of males and females who opted out or have lapsed coverage was roughly equal.

To help members remain covered on the scheme, DPS premiums are kept low and affordable. The yearly premium ranges from $36 for members aged 34 and below, to $260 for members aged 55 to 59. If a member's Ordinary Account balance is insufficient, DPS premiums can be paid from the member's Special Account. Most members should have little difficulty affording the premium so long as they are working. However, as with all insurance policies, the premiums cannot be waived and the coverage will lapse when there is non-payment.

Measures are also in place to minimise the DPS opt-out and lapse rates. When members request to opt out of the DPS, the insurers will ensure that they are fully aware of the consequences of opting out before accepting their request to do so. In particular, members are informed that if they decide to rejoin the DPS in future, their application will be subject to them being in good health, as required at the point of auto-inclusion.

To minimise lapse rates due to insufficient CPF balances, members receive notifications via mail to remind them to pay their DPS premiums in cash. All members will be given a final notice before the DPS coverage is terminated. Those who wish to re-join the scheme subsequently can apply to do so.

We will continue to review the DPS to ensure that it meets members' needs. For example, we have noted public feedback that the current auto-inclusion age of 16 may be too low for most members, as they are unlikely to have dependants at that age. We will also continue to look into other ways to reduce the lapse rates, to help more members stay covered.

Page: 573

Update on Special Employment Credit Scheme

34 Ms Mary Liew asked the Acting Minister for Manpower if he will give an update on the Special Employment Credit scheme, particularly how much has been disbursed to date and how many employees have benefited from the scheme.

Mr Tan Chuan-Jin : The Special Employment Credit (SEC) was introduced in 2011 to support employers and to raise the employability of older low-wage Singaporean employees. To date, $35.9 million has been paid out to 58,000 employers for employing 189,000 eligible older Singaporeans in 2011.

In 2012, the SEC was significantly enhanced to provide greater incentive to help employers attract and retain older Singaporeans. The age criterion was lowered to age 50, when it was previously age 55. The income cut-off was raised to $4,000 per month, when it was previously $1,700 per month. The SEC payout was also raised to 8% of the monthly wage, which means that the maximum payout (of $240 per worker per month) has been increased by about seven-fold.

The first payment of the enhanced SEC, for eligible workers hired in the period January to June 2012, will be made to employers in September 2012. Eighty-five thousand employers (a 50% increase) will receive about $230 million (more than a six-fold increase) for employing 383,000 eligible Singaporeans (a two-fold increase) in the first half of 2012. Among Singaporean workers aged 50 and above, about 85% were eligible for the SEC.

The Government encourages employers to take advantage of the SEC by hiring older workers. We should learn to appreciate and value older workers for their valuable experience and expertise. As our population ages and our labour market remains tight, organisations will position themselves well for the future when they embrace older workers as part of their workforce.

Page: 573

Guidelines to Protect Lower Wage Workers from Wage Reductions

35 Miss Penny Low asked the Acting Minister for Manpower what guidelines are in place to ensure that lower wage workers like cleaners are protected from wage reductions whenever their original company's contract expires and a new company takes over the contract, staff and machinery with a lower bid for the new contract.

Mr Tan Chuan-Jin : The Government shares Miss Penny Low's concern for cleaners. Cleaners are a group of workers which the Government is giving special attention to. While most low-wage workers have enjoyed income growth, cleaners have seen their wages fall over the last 10 years.

One reason for this is that the cleaning sector is often subject to the problem of cheap sourcing, where service buyers award contracts mainly based on price. As a result, cleaning companies bid aggressively low to win contracts and cut costs by reducing benefits and depressing wages. When this takes place, cleaners bear the brunt in terms of lower wages, poor employment conditions and few opportunities to up-skill themselves.

Page: 574

The Ministry of Manpower and its tripartite partners have promoted best sourcing to tackle cheap sourcing. The Tripartite Advisory on Best Sourcing Practices was released in 2008 and updated in January 2012. A complementary step-by-step guidebook was also released to provide buyers with practical information to implement best sourcing. NTUC administers the Best Sourcing Initiative (BSI) scheme which provides one-time funding equivalent of up to 5% of the outsourced contract value, capped at $150,000, to support companies in adopting best sourcing. This was recently raised from $75,000.

As a buyer of services, such as cleaning, the Government has announced its commitment to best sourcing. Starting from early next year, all new Government cleaning contracts will only be awarded to accredited cleaning companies. This also applies to contracts that come up for renewal.

In addition, the Government has announced it will be strengthening NEA's Clean Mark accreditation scheme, which recognises higher-quality service providers in the cleaning industry. While NEA will launch the full set of enhanced criteria later, a few new employment-related criteria are ready. These include requiring cleaning companies to (i) pay their cleaners' salaries through GIRO to facilitate prompt and regular salary payments, (ii) attain at least bizSAFE 17 Level 1 status to demonstrate the capability to manage safety and health risks, and (iii) not have defaulted on Labour Court orders 18 .

With the strengthening of the accreditation scheme, cleaners will need to be better trained, meet higher standards and become more productive. Because of cheap sourcing, however, the market on its own may not translate these requirements into higher wages for cleaners.

For this reason, the Government had earlier also announced that it will introduce a new requirement into the accreditation scheme for cleaners to receive appropriate wages commensurate with the training and higher standards, skills and productivity expected in the cleaning industry. This new requirement would ensure that local cleaners are fairly remunerated, as well as encourage the cleaning industry to focus on raising productivity rather than reducing wage costs. More details will be announced later.

17 bizSAFE is a capability building programme of the Workplace Safety and Health Council, and is intended to assist companies to fulfil their obligations under the Workplace Safety and Health Act, to put in place risk management.
18 Labour Court orders are issued after the Commissioner for Labour hears the salary claims lodged by the claimant and makes a decision on whether the claim is valid.
